pros: Teammates are intelligent and committed to actually solving problems, not just punching in and punching out against the clock. review_title: Great place to learn, not sure about long term
job_title: Operations Analyst in Jersey City, NJ
pros: GS is a great place to start your career at and learn everything you need to know about the corporate world and the product you are in. The culture is pretty remarkable, but a bit reminiscent of a cult. People are generally nice and easily approachable, especially when it comes to senior management and will gladly meet up with you over lunch to share their experience and give you some good tips in career progression. They also have a very impressive benefits package, which will be important to those who have families and need the coverage.
cons: Your work/life balance is almost non existent. If you want to be successful, you will need to make a 50/60 hr week your norm, and this is in Operations and not IBD division! It is also very hard to move from Ops into middle office or front office space, unless you have good connections, so better start networking from Day 1 when you join the company!

review_title: Strong, admirable company culture that isn't always reflected by all teams or individuals
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: The firm overall really does work hard to ensure employees have the resources they need to be successful. From personal wellness classes, multiple corporate perks, and affinity networks to the robust 360 degree reviews and comprehensive training materials and professional skills classes. For self-motivated individuals, you will learn a tremendous amount from working here.
cons: Despite structured frameworks to promote a positive, healthy culture, there are many managers who circumvent these parameters. For example, despite 360 degree feedback, upper management still dictates the year-end performance review. At the end of the day, there is still a very strong undercurrent of politics despite the claim to be a meritocracy. This distracts from people doing real work and rewards people who spend more time self-promoting.

job_title: Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great benefits (excluding pay) including a lot of vacation days.  Company promotes cultural diversity and is very much against any type of discrimination.  Once management likes you there are lots of opportunities to learn new things and get your name out there.  Work is challenging and fast paced in a good way.  You will be tested in all aspects and if in the end GS in not a right fit for you this will be a great benefit elsewhere.  There are a lot of smart people that know how to solve problems and work hard -  many opportunities to learn from them.
cons: Long hours are the norm.  You're expected to give a little bit too much of yourself to the job.  Peer reviews are a very large part of how employees are evaluated so that opens you up to backstabbing and co-workers writing bad reviews full of half-truths or even flat out lies.  You hope management will see through that and not penalize you.  Compensation in support roles/operations is not enough for the amount of work and effort put in.

pros:
Top of the ladder for investment banks, bragging rights amongst other friends on the street (though you quickly feel identified as a tool when around normal people) 
Good job security and comp for those that have been there a while and have broken through the steep learning curve and unique operating practices.
cons:
Long hours, you can work less and make more elsewhere on the street
Survives mostly on reputation, which doesn't really apply to  tech roles.
Development role involved mostly 1st line business support on archaic, proprietary, poorly designed system (stressful)
Poor dissemination of tech knowledge/documentation past your initial initiation training.
Slang/SecDB is indeed an interesting platform with great ideas, but the tools and UIs are ancient and make those used to more modern development environments wince.
Lateral experienced hires take a significant hit as the tech knowledge you can carry in is minimised.
Technology is lead mostly out of the Quant area, not IT, leading to poor quality, complicated code.

review_title: Very long hours and pressure but still great place to work for but you need to earn it with sacrifice and dedication.
job_title: Vice President in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Prestige.  Very ambitious and smart people.   Always things to learn.   Thorough review system and career development/mentoring (as long as you keep your eyes open).
cons: Very long hours and weekends even compared to other investment banks.   Could get aggressive.   (As with other firms) Tend to get political as you move up higher.   Sometimes too much emphasis on the 'perception/image' rather than the actual  outcome/impact.

review_title: Good pay, but I wasn't satisfied with the quality of work
pros:
- Good pay
- Excellent management. Managers are always looking to help you out in anyway and listen to your issues if you have any.
- Excellent feedback system
- If you're interested in more of finance and less of technology, this is the perfect place to be
cons:
- Too much of context switching. You'd have to switch between supporting users, handling production issues and doing your project work. The switch is so often that you don't feel a sense of accomplishment of a task by the end of the day.
- There's very little to learn being a technologist. You'd learn about finance and the markets, but your technology learning curve flattens pretty quickly.
- Very bad work life balance. People tend to come in by around 10 and stay back till 8. Though the managers are perfectly ok by you coming early and leaving early, you wouldn't feel good about leaving early cuz almost the entire team would still be there working.

review_title: Great Place to Start a Career
job_title: Business Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: GS is a fantastic place to start a career.  They teach you so much and expect even more.  The management is very open to answering questions and teaching up and coming employees.  There is a very strong office culture and an office-wide desire to provide the best.  It is very challenging, fast-paced and interesting.  This is the kind of place where sprinters thrive.  However, how many of us can sprint through a marathon?
cons:
First off, the pay is horrible.  They almost brag about their ability to pay the lowest possible amount to keep an employee.  I advanced several times, and my pay always seemed to be about the same.  It is hard to justify an increase in responsibility, time, and expectation without compensation being reciprocated.  
Secondly, the reviews are a farce.  Your manager, who gathers all the reviews from your peers, has the ultimate deciding factor of what your final score will be.  They can drop it to whatever they want regardless of your peer ratings.  I have sat in review sessions and watched this very thing happen.

review_title: If you are in it for the money, great place. Otherwise .....
job_title: IT Analyst in New York, NY
pros: In the IT world, there is a great team spirit, when it comes to people working on the same level. Many people are willing to help out - but then again, I think that is IT community and not just in Goldman. There are many resources to go to for help and many chances to do what you like, if you're willing to work for it. Most people I have worked with in IT are very open and willing to help. Also, let's be honest, Goldman does have a reputation of the bonuses and, compared to other places, it delivers upon those rumors.
cons: There is very little encouragement for balancing work with everything else - it is assumed that people have to work a lot. There is a great deal of politics, if you cannot or do not want to play by that, you will not get far, nor will you want to. There is always much to do and no time to do it, and obviously, everything is top priority. Multi-tasking often translates into "multi-head-ache-causing" tasking

review_title: A good place to work if you are happy to bed in and work hard but you can't move around easily. Competitive...
job_title: Operations Technical Specialist in City of London, England

review_title: If in Tech, run away from this place.

pros: There are some genuinely honest and decent people working here.

At best, you'll end up with a brand name on your resume, but the bureaucracy and politics of this place will destroy your soul.

job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros:

It's kill or be killed. Once you get past analyst and associate level, it doesn't matter the years of service or what you did a couple years ago. if you're not bringing in revenue today, you get judged on today. If you kick butt, that's fine - much more scary if you have an off quarter. 

Performance reviews are all politics and newbies who don't get the game are almost guaranteed to get crappy ones. They also are VERY vague about feedback. Total crapshoot on whether you have any idea if you're gonna get a 1st tier or get sacked.

job_title: Vice President Engineering in Jersey City, NJ

Big company comes with many restricting policies by the Feds, which limits personal trading and requires more paperwork to get seemingly stuff done. More paperwork means less focus on what you think is job-relevant.
The company blocks (has to block) many web sites because they might allow you to post text that it cannot retain & track, unfortunately that includes many sites that can be very useful for developers (google groups, blogs, ...).

review_title: Hard work, but rewarding in long run

review_title: Excellent Place to Launch a Career
pros: Flat organization with great great people, lots of access to senior management, fast-paced and challenging work environment ensures you'll never be bored, lots of opportunity to work on different things and transfer to different departments (if you're a high performer) & outstanding benefits.   Goldman really puts a lot of emphasis on their people, in developing them and having an open environment that's conducive to learning & progress.

pros:

Obverall great place to work.
cons:
Mobility is difficult.  Mobility opportunities are encouraged but not practiced. At times, very political. Good talent is lost because of this.

At times, very top heavy.  Teams are packed with middle to senior management, and there is a heavy reliance on junior members.  Progression hits a ceiling because of this, and when junior members who want to stay at the firm look for internal opportunities for growth in a different role, mobility is nearly impossible because a team relies so heavily on that junior person. Top performers have been lost because of this.

pros:

The firm is really making an effort to catch up with tech firms to avoid losing talent.  Commendable effort but still a ways to go.

The firm puts a lot of emphasis on training and mentoring young people.  A great place to work if you're a sponge ready to soak it all up.

People strived to always be better--it is infectious.

Improve internal mobility.    The firm is big enough that they'd be able to lose 10-30% of analysts leaving if they improved and even encouraged it for those people looking for a challenge.

At the end of the day, the firm has a fiduciary duty to its shareholders, so GCs and revenue will determine a lot.

The firm needs to weed out people who are detrimental to the firm's reputation even if they are top performers.

review_title: Exposure to latest Technologies, but not so-great management
pros:

Work-life balance is pretty good. You get to work with smart people. You also have a lot of flexibility to move between different teams.
cons:
Projects takes really long to finish, as there is no project management. Goldman has a flat structure, meaning there is no one manager. If you are in a place other than New York, that there is lesser visibility of your work, which gets accentuated by lack of management. Senior management(MD and above) is most of the times detached with projects and work accomplished within teams.

Goldman also hires a lot based on your communication skills, and A-performers, which reduces overall balance of personality types in a team, where everybody wants to compete with each other and there is no team work. Emphasis on communication skills, over technical skills makes it rather difficult to get a lot of technical projects completed in an efficient manner.

review_title: GS:  Looks Great on a Resume but the life/culture is not for everyone.

I had many friends who attempted us GS's internal job posting to get a position and all were rebuffed.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
You get to work with great, sharp, execution-oriented people. In front-office technology roles, you learn the business and people skills, not just technical skills. I'm paid well and I appreciate the prestige and respect comes with working at Goldman. The people I work with are a joy to work with. They are humble, fun, very sociable, and very professional. Everyone is very well put together and affable.

Honestly, I absolutely love working at Goldman, so don't let my below nitpicks make you think I don't. The only way for us to improve is for us to be transparent about—and focus on–our issues. So I'm going to focus on the nitpicks. If you can live with them, then JOIN! Because I'm pretty much covering every nit-picky grievance I have. (Really.) I think things are largely moving in the right direction, and that's what matters most, as it tells me that we are aware of our deficiencies, and we're actively working to improve them.

No place is perfect, but Goldman is certainly among the very best places to work. I feel very happy, privileged, honored, and humbled to be a member of Goldman's "family."
cons:
There are lots of meetings and distractions to juggle as a technologist. There's always more to get done then there is time for. Sometimes projects aren't properly designed in order to meet the pressure of deadlines, and you end up building a Leaning Tower of Pisa. You usually have to perform support tasks (on that leaning tower) while simultaneously developing new features. After you've helped resolve issues, the same people come back and ask what the status is on the project delivery timeline… in a meeting you're spending time with them in, of course. Some in the business will ask why a bug existed and how we can stop them going forward, as though we knew about them to begin with and left them in. (Have they ever read the notes on any phone app update? Find one that didn't include bug fixes! Unfortunately, bugs happen. Please be understanding.)

There's also a lot of proprietary in-house tech. Goldman often chooses to re-invent the wheel, instead of using an open source library, or contributing to them, for that matter. In the end, it's a losing play that doesn't scale; better solutions are inevitably created when you collaborate with the world, and you gain knowledge-sharing gravity when you do so. Documentation is often lacking as well.

review_title: Exactly what you'd expect it to be

Proficiency - There are some truly brilliant people working there. If you have a chance to work with them and pick their brain on a daily basis, you will learn more about the industry in a few years than many people do in their entire career. However, this is not the vast majority of the population at Goldman - my coworkers tend to agree with the following demographic breakdown: 10% brilliant, 60% slightly above average (but think being at GS makes them brilliant), 30% trying to escape and don't care.
cons: Leadership - It doesn't exist here. People are promoted to management positions based on their ability to make money, absent any consideration of their leadership potential. As a result, very few teams have anything but a toxic work environment with ineffective leaders.

review_title: not the firm it once was
pros: Plenty of smart people remaining; their proprietary technology is interesting
cons:
l left GS after working for 10+ years in their tech division. Here are a few reasons why : 

Standards are slipping. In the past 5 years, many jobs such as DBAs and SAs have been off-shored to India to save money. Turnover in these locations is high and the quality of the staff is often lacking. lt's rare to find anyone in these roles who is skilled and takes a genuine interest in what they're doing.

The amount of regulation and red tape has reached absurd levels. A simple task such as getting a server rebooted becomes a bureaucratic nightmare, involving multiple levels of manager approval followed by repeated emails, phone calls and hours of waiting. Don't even think about downloading a cool piece of productivity software onto your PC. You'll first need to check whether the app has been approved for use at GS, then get your manager to sign off, and finally open a ticket to have it installed remotely. If your app isn't on the approved list, forget it.

By the way, India is never, ever referred to as a "low cost" location at GS - it's "high value", to use the correct GS-speak, To survive in the corporate hierarchy, you'll also need to learn how to "reach out" to somebody (= talk to them), to "revert" to an email (= reply), and how to "leverage" virtually any object (= use it), I know GS doesn't have a monopoly on this sort of double-speak, but I always find it faintly worrying to see how otherwise intelligent people parrot these tired phrases without a hint of irony or self awareness.

Perhaps the most-used buzzword in recent years is "industrialization" - as in replacing human jobs with software, Management claim that industrialization will free people from routine or boring jobs, allowing them to spend time in more creative activities (there's never been an attempt to automate any MD- or partner-level jobs, although those are probably the most amenable - wonder why ??) 

It's difficult to criticize GS for wanting to cut costs, but it's dispiriting to think that your job in IT is essentially to put other people out of a job. Earlier in my career, GS was about using harnessing human intelligence to solve complicated business problems (and being paid well, because we were doing something that few others firms could). Increasingly we seem to be engaged in a race to the bottom, chasing ever-shrinking margins with as few overheads as possible, The relentless drive for efficiency makes for a pretty unappealing work environment - desks have been "densified" (another lovely GS-ism), office plants have been removed, and even the waste baskets have vanished. 

Don't expect to be be particularly well paid. I guarantee that you will quickly become fed up of reading about the "average" GS bonus payout in the media, and then having to explain to friends and family that you're only paid a fraction of that amount. I used to be proud of the fact that I worked as GS, now I try to avoid mentioning the name,

The annual 360 reviews can also be pretty dispiriting. Over the years I've had reviews across the scale. Doing well seems largely to be a question of being in the right role and knowing the right people. Don't fall for the rhetoric about meritocracy - working hard and doing a good job is no guarantee of success. Personally i'd far rather the whole system were junked - I've had to deliver a few bad reviews in my time, and it's unpleasant and often utterly demotivating for the recipient.

Oh, and prepare for endless cheerleading about the benefits of diversity and multiculturalism. The training is mandatory, so no sense complaining. But the sad reality is that "diversity in the workplace" often translates into hiring candidates who simply wouldn't have made it through the door 10 years ago.

I loved my early years at GS, but I would not be tempted to re-join the firm today.

pros: Wow, upper management is really pushing for top tech. Which is awesome if you are in Tech or Starts division. pros:

review_title: Do the job right and you will love GS

pros: When full time the bonus is always great, the benefits are the best, work from home flexibility, the harder you work the faster you will move up but you have to speak up or they will think you dont want more responsibility, easy to move within the company- they would rather move you than fire you, if you ever consider moving out of GS - expect at least a 15-20k salary increase. they will not give you feedback unless you go back to your agency and the agency calls HR which in turn calls the manager who probably seats next to you.

job_title: Vice President Senior Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Surrounded by very bright people.  Great place to work for driven individuals who require only the minimum managerial oversight.  The culture can wildly vary depending on which team you join.  Firm in general has a desire of building their own solutions over vendor products which means you’ll always have some new interesting initiative to build (even if it’s just rebuilding what an open-source would already provide).
cons:
Preference to build rather than buy technology solutions means a profuseness of buggy libraries and services with little or no documentation and support.  Often integrating with such systems hinges on the success of who you know that can point you in the right direction (“talk to so-so who may be able to refer you to someone who may know somebody that has a foggy memory of how you use that convoluted API”).

Team cultures vary.  I’ve worked on close-knit groups where everyone worked hard for the common goal, while other teams I’m just a headcount regardless of my contributions.

review_title: Amazing place to launch your career... Some work here for decades...
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in London, England
pros:
1. One of the best financial services place to launch your career after school 

2. Their new analyst entry/grad programme is great

3. Job mobility between teams, divisions and regional offices (or a combination of those) is encouraged

4. As an American company, the amazing firm culture from New York flows to global offices to some extent. You can be in any office and know you are in the same firm

5. Work/Life balance partly depends on you, manager/team and the division your work in
cons:
1. Pay in non-revenue generating divisions are not as great as it used to be. Management are not fixing this as quickly as expected for the oldies but are focusing on being competitive for new grads. They are losing talented engineers to tech companies 

2. The extended New York training for new grad Technology/Engineering is not available at the moment

3. Skills gained in a role that focusses on the company's proprietary software are not transfarable

4. While the company provides useful programs, tools and facilites for employee self-development, you are ultimately responsible for driving your career

pros: There some great people who you feel lucky to work with and the culture generally works well. There are often interesting speakers at the GS talks and the  in-house gym and medical facilities are fab.
cons: Whilst the firm aided by HR give plenty of lip service to GS being a meritocracy it's not necessarily the case. In GSAM in particular they tend to ship over Americans to senior positions totally often ignoring home grown talent from the London office. There are a number of things which could be improved on such as the internal mobility policies - HR should be doing more here to facilitate.

review_title: Bad place for technologists. Long hours, poor work-life balance.
pros:
Some very smart people. Salaries paid are average, bonuses (when given) are excellent. 

Certain divisions are very interesting places to work.
cons:
Goldman is definitely not the place for strong technology folks who have spent time in tech companies in the past. You will probably get bored supporting existing legacy systems. The environment and culture are also very different. Technologies supported are old and (some) proprietary. Work hours are long, 12+ hours every day.

The career ladder forces people to choose at some point between the managerial or technology path. This is the only place in the industry where an excellent technical person can not also be a manager of a tech team. Everybody has to make a choice at some point about her/his career path and you end up having people that may not understand technology well, or are afraid of its challenges,  choosing the managerial path. Mid-level management inexperience is one of the biggest problems in the company. There is no career growth for technical people once they reach the senior levels of the VP position.

Be prepared to work with some people that are arrogant.

review_title: Challenging 10 weeks, in a bad way
job_title: Summer Associate in New York, NY
pros:
Some folks were great, a lot of folks were fine.
The exposure to senior level meetings and decision making was truly valuable.
cons:
Naturally, the hours were bad, but presumably you know what you are signing up for.  I had worked long hours before but it is much harder without the sense of teamwork, camaraderie, and gratitude from senior folks.
A few people were genuinely malicious and there was no way to protect yourself from them and no recourse when you were mistreated.  Before I started people told me that a lot of backstabbing goes on at Goldman.  I didn't really know what that meant until a few weeks into my summer.  
Most people were smart enough, but they didn't seem to be anything exceptional.  If anything, the experience gives you the sense that smartest guys on Wall Street really aren't that clever.
The simplistic level of the financial analyses and the lack of thought that goes into the inputs to analyses was eye-opening.

job_title: Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
- Decent Comp
- Brand Name 
- Intelligent coworkers
- Good benefits 
- Recent positive improvements to the internal mobility platform
cons:
Operations work for the most part is mind numbing and repetitive. People are used as patches for the processes that haven't yet been automated. This leads to daily work that doesn't build any transferable skills. What knowledge you do manage to build is usually rooted in the technical aspect of the firms system, and will eventually become obsolete once they roll out a system update. 

Depending on your managers compensation and promotions can be very closely tied to office politics. It is almost impossible to stand out as a high performer through your daily work alone. Which means that a lot of analyst spend time doing useless project work on top of the daily work load just to get recognition from senior managers. 

I think GS can be a great place to work if you are in a different division but would recommend people avoid ops at all costs.

review_title: Mormon Goldman Sachs--You're in or out!
job_title: Senior Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT

cons: Managers don't help you train you. You're left to your own devices to learn your function. If you don't do a good job it's your fault! Good luck not being mormon. GS stresses people to come up with innovative ideas but they use that as an elimination device to purge employees that do not fit with the culture or quietly acquiesce to the will of their senior managers.

review_title: A much worthwhile career experience @ GS
pros: GS is the sort of place that every cell of your body has to be awake around the clock, 24/7 and the drill starts in every corner of the daily business - you are either ready or incompetent.  The 14 business principles really reach its employees at all levels and help shape the company's productivity as it is right now.  Time management, multi-tasking and politics - you can learn so much here from that treadmill work style.
cons: The hectic schedules at your desk and' Monkey Business' doubts at the back of your head may lead to some dizziness if  you can NOT stay ahead of the competition too often.  That mess wont easily be dismissed because a place like GS only needs the best of you, nothing less.

review_title: Good experience for recent grads, even though the role might not be a good fit
job_title: Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT

cons: There's very little flexibility once you've joined the firm. Hard to switch or move around if you feel that your role and/or location isn't a good fit for you. Might not be an experience exclusive to GS but many other banks will make an effort to switch analysts between roles if it doesn't appear to be a good fit.

review_title: Mixed Bag - you will learn a lot but you will also get burned
job_title: Vice President, Compliance in New York, NY
pros: You will work with incredibly smart and driven people. The benefits are good and there is focus on wellness and resilience. The Goldman name makes it really easy to get a huge comp bump and promotion when you leave.
cons: The work environment is incredibly intense and needlessly so. Management does not take a long view but rather jumps from one crisis to the next. Teams are short staffed which contributes to the constant need to put out fires rather than think about mitigating risk long term. In order to get a promotion, you need to play the politics game. Unfortunately there are some toxic individuals in senior leadership who will prevent anyone but their favorites from being promoted/get raises. Just doing a good job will not get you ahead -- you will need to lobby for promotions and raises.

review_title: A great opportunity to work your tail off...

review_title: Rat race. Fundamentally dysfunctional organization. (Tech Division)
pros: Good company reputation and recognition, although continually waning.  Competitive base salary.  Nice gym.
cons: Close to impossible internal mobility.  Long working hours is a given here as mentioned by others. Work life balance is a joke.  On boarding of new employees is chaotic and unstructured.  In Technology Division, there is no defined professional development in place.  Skills learned are mostly proprietary since the tools used are home-grown and are not transferable elsewhere in the industry.  A common internal mantra -- 'your network is your net worth' promotes a culture of exclusivity.  The annual team review is unfair and frequently 'gamed' by those who are in the know. If you get an offer to work in Technology, be sure to be ask for the coveted title of 'senior engineer'.  It takes years to earn this title even if one has proven prior experience.

review_title: Not a place for a long term career
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
Opportunity to work with very talented people.
Great place to start your career and get it on your resume.
Unless you are on track to make partner, GS is not the best place for a long term career. If you are on track to make partner, be willing to sell your soul for the title and $
cons: The Goldman brand premium is quickly dissipating. Compensation is not what it used to be, the industry is going through difficult times and high pressure and expectations remain the same.

review_title: Great to have on CV, not worth the stress long term
pros:
Great learning experience especially soft skills in how to get things done with no info or resources and no local knowledge
In IT, developers do everything and managers are very technical, most still write code. Almost no business analysts or project managers or other non-technical roles 
Work with very smart people 
Having them on CV opens all doors
Bonuses are unbelievable if you can qualify
cons:
Tough competitive environment,  rating against peers including overseas who are in much better position. Help is hard to find and is discouraged, making the environment more stressful than it should be
Very flat structure and small presence in Australia, hard to get promoted unless move to other locations 
In IT, high use of proprietary systems and even their own programming language, the longer you're there the harder it is to find work elsewhere

pros: Worked in risk management, saw that company leadership did respect risk. In a pricing dispute between trader and controller, tie went to the controller. Company was able to produce a daily estimated balance sheet. I don't believe this is the case at other Wall Street banks. This culture of risk is what saved the firm during the 2008 Financial Crisis.
cons: Really intense and demanding culture, people get burned out, I was surprised at how little infrastructure/processes were built out in my group, i.e. no regular meeting rhythm between analysts/associates and VPs, scheduled ad hoc. There is summer training but you mostly learn everything on the job. Most people are very smart but not necessarily good teachers.

pros:
By definition the best-in-class bank to work at. Everybody knows it, and more importantly, the people inside know it. There's an unparalleled sense of pride in work and collaboration that stems from being #1, as much flak as you get for saying or even acknowledging it.

It sounds cliche, but the lessons you learn there from work and people teach you how to handle anything else for the rest of your life. You learn extreme ownership and you learn to keep jumping upward.
cons: Mentally taxing to keep up a facade or to have your guard up 18 hours a day. Things you say will be fact-checked on the spot, thoughts you have will be analyzed and responded to. You develop an involuntary filter where you either say minimally or source everything you say. Some people naturally adapt to this and carry it into their personal lives. If you haven't been there long enough it won't. Some may think it's better to have the balance however.

review_title: A challenging and fulfilling work environment for all talent groups.

cons:
*Capitalistic outlook. A good year will get you great returns in terms of hikes and other benefits. A bad year can drive you really hard.
*Not much of work life balance as releases happen after trading ends in New York, which invariable ends up being weekends for us in Bangalore.

pros: Great pay, and prestige - industry leader in investment banking, and great opportunity to build career and resume. After 2 years a GS, I get an interview to any finance related job I apply for within my experience level. Overall fantastic experience here.

review_title: Great experience if you can handle the workload

The name Goldman Sachs is as good as gold on a resume when you decide to look elsewhere.

Either you are identified early on as a start and moved up the ladder accordingly, or you more or less stay at the same level.  Performance review is supposed to be objective and 360-degree but mostly results in back-scratching and rampant grade inflation.

review_title: Good opportunity for growth and high rewards, but only if you have confidence, patience and more than a bit of luck
pros: Reputation was very good, before the whole industry blew up. Is still recognised as among best in field, and times will turn again. Leadership is really excellent, clear sense of direction and give a sense of confidence. Generally equitable treatment of employees, good work progression / career advancement
cons: Opacity of salary structure and lack of comparison with others. If you do not have much experience you will not be paid your fair market value as inexperience is something you pay a price for (although I believe that is the same at most large companies). Lack of work life balance can be an issue however not if you manage it well. Middle management can be very slow and opaque in communicating big changes but again that is the same at most companies of a certain size and to an extent is the function of middle management.

job_title: IT Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Job stability and thought leadership forums. These forums bring leaders from around the world, and they come to speak here at Goldman to deliver a presentation.
cons:
Working at Goldman Sachs Asset Management "technology" feels more like a glorified support center. There's alot of things to do, but it's just  1 to 3 day "projects". It feels like plumbing work...you are always fixing something. Stay out if you already have technology experience. You will not learn much here.

Be prepared to write SQL select statements all day trying to figure out what data is missing in the systems.

review_title: Great place to work. Smart and motivated people although very stressful. Long hours.
job_title: Technology Analyst in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
- Very reputable company.
- People are smart, very motivated, and driven.
- Decent vacation days.
- People always come up with smart ideas/better ways to do things.
- Good internal mobility.
- Global company, sometimes you get to travel to offices in other regions. Chance to constantly work with people from all regions on a day-to-day basis.
- People are very nice (not arrogant like some people think) and open to ideas.
cons:
- Very stressful at times. Long hours and high expectations. 
- During an ongoing project it's difficult to take days off, or even if you're sick you still need to work from home otherwise work won't get done.
- Political at times. Sometimes promotions depend on your manager.
- Up or out kind of culture.

pros:
1. Company take care of you very well regarding the external benefits.
2. Doctors are available all time here.
3. You got to learn to be more lot of soft skills.
cons:
1. No onsite 
2. Show off works than talent
3. NAPA (New joinee from college) are paid and taken care well compared to experienced, it's a different culture, learn to experience it if you are planning to join ;)
4. Severe cost saving, they have increased the food prices 3X times and cab facilities as well.
5. If tech want to feel BPO culture this is the place, start at ~7 every one will hook on to there headphones for a call with NY office. Remember NY will never stretch for India.
6. Bonus are unpredictable, and not good from past 3-4 years.
7. Slow growth, remember only SHOW OFF works or you should be a NAPA :( .

review_title: Survival of the smartest, fastest and most creative minds.
job_title: Operations Analyst in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
* great place to develop fundamental professional skills (written and oral communications, project management, etc.).
* able to develop your own leadership style
* travel opportunities
* able to lead early in career 
* you make more money than your peers in the industry
cons:
* no free time to spend the money you make so you end up shopping online and not having time to return the merchandise that you do not want. 
* not as progressive on the "home office" front as some other firms are. There is still an emphasis on "face time"
* there is no such thing as a standard 40 hour work week. Be prepared to work 60-70hrs a week (U.S).
* your social life becomes centered around your work schedule

pros:
1. The company has a good culture. Ppl are respectful, nice, and willing to help.
2. A great company to go for the first job out of school
3. Salt Lake City is very cheap to live in a decent life. (you can get a fancy 1b1b apartment for less than $1200/ month)
4. You have GS under your resume.
cons:
1. Honestly, SLC office is a giant in-house outsource center for GS. The most of teams are doing things that ppl in NY don't even bother to do.
2. Hard to move laterally to hub cities' GS offices (some ppl can, It's like one out of ten chance), so you want to use SLC experience to leverage into NY HQ, think twice.
3. The work is boring AF, and your learning curve will plateau after three months.
4. Turnover is high. It is depressing when you constantly see people you know leaving the firm. 
5. It's Utah, not NYC, there is not that much finance opportunity in SLC.

pros:
High compensation potential if you're in a client facing group
Educational Assistance
Can get exposure quickly to the industry
cons:
Leadership has no direction and is cliquey/unaccessible
Leadership pretends to be open but if you say something they don't like...
Perpetually understaffed with high turn over
Low compensation in starting years
Performance isn't as individual as it should be - get ride of people that can't perform, set higher standards for new hires, and reward those who go above and beyond. Everything good/bad is looked at through your groups lens.

job_title: Experienced Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: in general organization is very good. It really takes care of its employees. it offers good benefits and health plans
cons:
good organization to work for BUT the experience really depends on the team. People are promoted based on how good their relationships are with higher management and not on the basis of the quality of work and value they are adding. Managers are not aware of their team members skill set and they totally fail at creating opportunities for their career advancement. 
no acknowledgement or recognition for the people who are working for 11-12 hours a day. Their work goes unacknowledged.

review_title: Sachs treat their Contracted People Poorly
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great to see people work hungrily, eagerly and the bankers are ferocious at what they do. Those that are hungry play no games and it's inspirational to watch the fire as an Assistant or any capacity of lower tier positions. It's a brand so it will look good on paper.
cons: It's an overrated customer service job more than anything, tedious and poor treatment of people who are temps or contracted. They constantly remind you how you are "Not one of them" yet you are. Temps: No perks to the gym, discounts, small thank you bonuses for the harder work provided by temporary Assistants who are now coverage for the unreliable seniority.

review_title: Agility and collaborative environment is a work in progress
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Top notch medical benefits.  The teams are hard working and professional.  Good place for people starting out their career.
cons:
The organization is still working on understanding know how to work in a collaborative agile environment.   The current management team doesn't believe in the Agile framework and make it difficult to transition to an Agile and collaborative environment.  

ScrumMasters have difficult constraints engaging unsupportive management, limited career options and have unfair and unclear expectations.

The groups also don't have a strong ScrumMaster team structure which have resulted in ScrumMasters reporting to Dev Managers and Product owners which is not the best situation for ScrumMasters.

review_title: Think twice before you join them. You may be OK for a while but don't stay too long or you will turn into one of them
pros: Good pay. Looks good on your resume. Up to date with technical trends. Focus on technology. You get to work with some very competent people and learn a lot.
cons: It's a toxic culture. It's like swimming with the sharks. You sink or swim. It doesn't matter if you're good or bad at what you do. You have to literally be a shark to survive in that world.  People will step on your face and crush you to impress the next middle manager up the line. OK, they pay really well if you climb up the ladder, but you have to be willing to sell your soul to the devil.

review_title: Stay Away, even if the Goldman Sachs name might lure you in
pros: Ample Parking, Handful of nice people and not much after that.  Oh wait, the paycheck being direct deposited is a nice feature. And that's about it!
cons:
Horrible Pay
Long Hours +50 easy
401k matching doesn't start til you here for 5 years
Not a lot of holidays because we are market driven 
Upper management plays favoritism and its blatant
Administrators do all the grunt work
Interns don't really intern they are human copy & bind machines
You can't express your distaste about management or else you get written up or FIRED
ALL Ayco devices are monitored
Promotions are given to the ones management like more not by qualifications 
Be prepared to fake smile all day
I don't trust my manager as far as I go throw him. 
AYCO =  NoPayCo
If you want to leave my team, my manager will NOT help with the transfer cause he thinks his team is the best.

review_title: Great opportunity and quality work to do for the initiated
pros: At GS, front office developers always have their hands full - you'll never geeky bored. A long term strategic design and implementation, or a lesser effort short term tactical solution. The hierarchy is largely flat as anyone can contribute to a project as long as he/she can carry consensus on the point. The caliber of colleagues is superior, and their is a strong culture of teamwork. Middle management is willing to listen to you. Pays are best in industry, often to start with, and definitely once you've proven yourself. Often there are opportunities to relocate internally, if there is a good match and a justified business reason.
cons: The biggest challenge at GS is to find a good work life balance. Some people end up working very long hours without any regard for the time zone they are physically located in. Firm has tools to support working from home, and one should use these and find a flexible balance that suits oneself.

review_title: GS Operations is a great place to start If you want to be in finance or you don't have a plan out of college
job_title: Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
A little background about myself, I worked in the Salt Lake City Office which has grown to be the second biggest location in the United States and my entire career was in Operations Division.  Please take that into account.  I can't speak for Sales, Trading, or any other division outside of having to deal with them on a regular basis to get work done nor can I talk about the other office locations outside having visited a few and all are different.  Ops is great in that you can learn a lot of transferable skill sets and abilities that you can take to almost any job.  You are only niched into ops by your own lack of creativity if you think that ops is a dead end career choice post college.  I hope this helps puts things in perspective for a lot of you.  I still believe that overall this is a great place to start a career although I would doubt that its a place where people ultimately make their careers (at least in Ops).

Some Pros about GS is that

- Professional growth
If you don't know what you want to do in life running through the gauntlet that is Goldman Sachs is a smart move to build up your professional profile and skill set.  You will be forced into situations that take you out of your comfort zone and if you are lucky you will have some good people around you to help you prepare and learn from those experiences.  Every situation is treated with highest professional manner and everything you do is expected to be of the highest quality of work.  Every report should be accurate and concise, every email professional in tone and content, every analysis has every angle covered with good presentation and the appropriate content for the audience.  Everything matters and you better be sure your work is up to grade.  Don't be scared they will understand you are new to this the first few times you make a mistake.

- Smart people all around you
If you haven't realized it by now you will shortly that you are rarely the smartest person in the room (if you are currently that will change at GS).  These people are smart.  Very smart.  You can pull the wool over their eyes once or twice or maybe get by for awhile with a manager that doesn't care but in the long run (year or longer) you will be exposed.  Thats ok, you don't always have to be the smartest in the room you just can't take it personal every time someone calls you out in public or private and get better.  Again, this is Ops not other divisions.  Ops is not out to call you out every time you make a mistake or criticize you on every idea.  They do it its because the firm benefits more when your mediocre idea is vetted with other smart people and becomes a great proposal.  Don't take it personal. 

- High stress environment 
This is a pro and a con.  If you can handle a high stress environment you will thrive.  If you can't you will learn to or you will be looking for a new job shortly after joining.  GS puts a lot of pressure on you really quick.  Like I said before, what you do matters and sometimes you have to make really hard decisions in short periods of time because market is closing or client is threatening a walk or your manager doesn't want to lose his or her head and needs you to crunch some numbers yesterday.  Just know that once you overcome these obstacles you will be better for it.

- Responsibility is high for junior individuals
Another pro and con.  Almost the same speech from high stress environment.  

- Mentors
Rest assured the really good managers at GS (and they exist) understand that good junior analysts need good mentors to show them the ropes and take them under their wing.  GS will even match you up with one if you haven't found one on your own.  Just know that its on you to follow up with them and if you are smart you will have more than one and they will be strategically placed in positions that you can leverage.  Reach out to them, gain their insight and heed their advice because they have been there longer than you and guess what they are still there and successful so they must know what they are talking about.  Just don't restrict yourself to one, get many and get them from backgrounds that you are not comfortable with.  More perspectives will often change your own on a situation.  Take this advice; man walks in a desert when he surrounds himself with people that think and act like him.
cons:
- Work/Life balance
Forget it, you won't have one.  You work 10 hour days on a good day and 15+ on a bad day.  Your dog will drown in anxiety or chew up your sneaker collection, your wife will hate your job, your kids will wonder if you love them and your friends will inevitably people that work with you or in the same industry.  Assuming of course you are on the path to success at the firm.  Otherwise you may be able to pull off weekend getaways, the occasional afterwork drink and hey maybe even the gym to burn off all those donuts you ate your desk.

- High stress environment
Read above but if you can't handle being in a stressful, high strung, alpha environment where everything you do matters than please save yourself the therapy sessions and medical costs and try something else.

- The actual work can be boring
Yeah it sucks, especially at the analyst level.  Guess what? Processing transactions, data entry, project testing, trade settlement, account opening, etc all suck. They are not fun.  Not even a little.  But it gets better... you know when you are an Associate and you are leading a team of analysts doing something they hate for that almighty dollar.

- Corporate politics
This is not unique to GS.  For those that are in college are have never worked at a large organization please mentally prepare yourself for the office politics.  They are there and you are playing whether you like it or not.  You can choose not to play and hope by the good graces of Allah and Blankfein that you are noticed for your good work but I have a higher chance of getting that 10 at the gym to ask me out on date.  You are going to have to play.  Marathon some Suits on USA and learn up on office politics and keep yourself out of the crosshairs as much as you can.  Build friendships and network, don't through people under the bus, and don't take credit for someone else's work and you will be fine.  This is where a mentor will do you well.

- Compensation
Analyst level it sucks and you will kick yourself for it.  Stick it out and get lucky that the firm has a great year and you too can have a great year.  Just remember its based on how well the firm did, how well your business unit did, and how well you did.  Oh and you are also in ops which is at the end of the day a cost and not a revenue generating arm of the firm and so you will never get rich until you make MD.  Well off at VP but not rich.

- Senior Leadership
How can I say this.  Just because Michael Jordan was arguably the best player ever... doesn't mean he is a great coach.  Phil Jackson was a mediocre player and well look what he accomplished.  GS traditionally promotes Jordan's to management so prepare yourself. 

- Accountability
You should definitely have this.  Some people won't and some people will.  Sadly you will find there are large groups in GS Ops that are not.  You can't change them and unfortunately those that don't are what slows down good businesses.  Be accountable and you will be surprised on how fortunate that will be for you.  Heck, be accountable for other people, it shows leadership and managers will recognize that.

- Can't trade (oddly a big downer)
GS Ops cannot trade on personal accounts.  Well you can but only if you first check with your manager, the compliance lists and your mom.  Sadly almost every company is on some list that restricts you from trading.  Get used to indexes and big funds.  Its like working for Sam Adams and company policy says you cant drink... ever without asking them first.

- Grindhouse mentality for some areas
There are areas of GS Ops that are quite literally grindhouses.  They take you in, chew you up, and then spit you out when you are done.  Then they go out and get the next college kid and repeat.  Sorry its just how it is.  Learn what you can and transfer to another area if you want or leave but its their business model and it works for management.

review_title: Great place that I would go back to
pros: Amazing learning opportunities, attractive pay and bonus, great work ethic and culture, diverse and international environment, needless to mention the company reputation (and what it does to your CV), ....
cons:
Working hours are often over-rated, most is face time and it's just useless!

Also I got an offer for a job, and when I started was placed in a totally different team where we had ZERO personal fit, my boss hated me and the role was not at all what I wanted to do. No opportunity to use internal mobility before 18 months in the firm, so I quit

review_title: An Educational Experience that Opens Career Doors
pros:
Working at Goldman Sachs was an enjoyable and fulfilling experience.  There are ample opportunities for lateral movement within the firm should you prefer to switch groups or industries.  The firm excels at identifying and promoting talent.  Those who choose to leave the firm will have the Goldman stamp of approval, which looks amazing and opens doors.

Furthermore, the extremely efficient manner by which everything is run is incredibly admirable.
cons: The firm is full of hard-working, smart, and driven individuals with a naturally competitive streak and desire to be the best.  The work environment can be stressful with long hours; however, so long as you are aware of these cons going in, the firm is relatively meritocratic for such a large institution and fosters upward mobility for those who perform.

review_title: Amazing family orientated company with great ethos
job_title: Wealth Management Professional in New York, NY
pros: Some of the nicest most caring people you will ever meet. Goldman gets a bad rap in the press but I lost count of the number of times I witnessed employees put people over profit. This is a company that really cares about giving back. We recently packaged up a some sub-primes from the Malaysian markets, sold them to a commercial bank in Indiana, and then used the money from the sale to make more loans to people who needed houses. Sometimes I feel so proud when I arrive home because I have helped people realize their dreams of home ownership. Securitization is the pennicillin of the 21st century.
cons: We have to work with some real meanies in other investment banks; people that only care about making money and buying fancy clothes. The good thing is they make me realize that we are the good guys

job_title: Investment Banking Associate in New York, NY
pros: My team mates in investment banking were probably some of the most competent, hard working and genuinely smart people I’ve ever worked with. The firm genuinely lives up to its ethos of a team work oriented environment, and brings together individuals across departments in a highly cohesive manner to deliver a best in class product. Fantastic place to start your career. In case of any personal issues (such as family health concerns), the firm genuinely takes care of you by extending its full support.
cons: Issues typical of any large organisation - individuals are cogs in a well oiled machine, easily replaceable and operating in a highly competitive environment. While this isn’t completely a con in itself, focus on personal learning and development is diminished.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: You will learn a lot about how to work under stress and tight deadlines. If you are lucky like me you will end up in groups that strongly believe in testing. You can learn a lot about how to establish good working relationships with people you strongly dislike (a valuable skill in finance), and how to work with a large number of people at the same time because you will need to talk to them to be able to do your job (simply because basic procedures are not documented). Some managers know how to get things done, but manager quality is very inconsistent.
cons: The amount of stress can be enormous. In terms of compensation - no raise over 3 years in spite of promotion from Associate to VP and then becoming tech lead for a very important team does not seem right. At bonus comp time the mix of stock and cash is unknown - which is very stressful. Other places make the mix ratio is predetermined. When you leave, things can also get stressful in terms of getting everything the company owes you - I still have outstanding items they have not paid me for.

review_title: Good resume builder if you can handle mundane work...yawn
job_title: Senior Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Driven and motivated atmosphere/culture. Pretty good benefits. Downtown office is nice with great views. Good resume builder. Diversity.
cons:
Most of the positions in SLC are back office type positions where you won't get much, if any, face-time interaction with clients. There is a lot of mundane tasks that can be really mind numbing. You are just one of many "robots" and have your set of functions to complete the way they tell you (no deviating) on a daily basis. 

Most people can feel like they hit a wall in terms of learning as your day-to-day job responsibilities are quite repetitive with little room for creativity. You don't need to have a business degree to get hired at GS. Most jobs can be completed by anyone, really. 

Pay is on the lower end for the hours.

review_title: Taking the job was the best decision I have ever made and leaving was the second best...
job_title: Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great opportunity to learn and build your resume.  They hire from a lot of different backgrounds so it can be a great step into the industry.
cons: Lots of hours, high stress, incompetent management, a lot of talk and very little action.  The company is not all that it is cracked up to be.  Expect to feel like a cog in the wheel and expendable at any moment.

review_title: A few great people in a sea of mediocrity
pros:
Work with (mostly) smart people and get paid (in good years) a lot
Most people are very friendly and always willing to help
Learn about the financial system if you want
If you're smart and willing to network like crazy you can get ahead pretty far
cons:
Expect to work very long hours (jokingly referred to as Goldman hours)
Management is all about pleasing your next two levels of managers and impressing the rest
Mid level managers often see their reportees as either useful for advancement (cause they have good ideas) or cannon fodder for weekend work
If you can fake competence you're set
High level of risk aversion unless your back is protected, CYA is an artform
A lot of the best people have already left for Google, startups, etc. Only the slow and the ladder climbers remain

pros: There are many honest, good, intelligent professionals working at Goldman Sachs and you will have an opportunity to work with many of them.
cons: A highly political organization where your professional success is determined primarily based on which senior manager you work for than the quality of work.  Management expects every auditor to work 11 - 13 hours per day and each auditor to work on 2 - 3 audits at the same time.  A culture that encourages gossip and pointing out the mistakes of your peers rather than a supportive, team environment.  New college grads, sourced through the summer intern program, are used to replace leavers due to a consistently high turnover rate in the double digits annually.  A very observant summer intern recently commented to me during a one-on-one that "it appears most people don't want to be here".  She was spot on.

review_title: Good experience, smart people, but very political and performance dependent on manager
pros: Great employee benefits and pay. The office in New York has an amazing view of the river and the Financial District. They have very influential people that come and speak at the office. Everyone is very smart and you have access to a lot of great tools.
cons: Very long hours but you know that going in. Very political and unique culture. Performance isn't based on your capabilities or accomplishments as much as it is fitting well in the culture. Very formal, never casual. Very little transparency into bonus payments until a few days before. Company is very segregated in terms of revenue and federation divisions. The thing that made me leave was my manager. If  you get the wrong manager, your life can become a living hell.

pros: The gym is great and there is reasonable allowance to work from home.
cons:
Technology is a weak point at Goldman Sachs, internal tools and processes are far behind the industry standards. Additionally, there is a conflation between job title and experience which leaves senior management making the all too common statement "I want you to make me look smart". Either your are smart or you are not, masquerading as someone that knows what they are doing is not a formula for success. All too often Managing Directors with no technical experience are given direct leadership of a technical team. In such an environment judgement is absent and strategic decisions are based on personal relationships rather than on critical analysis. 

From my experience working here if you want to get ahead political manoeuvring will serve you better than hard work or technical capability.

review_title: I worked in operations.  My comments are biased towards that.
job_title: Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: If you survive the intense interviews and pass the 10yr background check you might just get a job with a company that has come to be respected for its talent.  The compensation is average to above depending on experience for my local area.  They have excellent orientation and skill building programs.  You will have a hard time finding better medical and vision benefits anywhere else.  Just working for a company like this gives you a lot more credibility in the workplace.
cons: In Salt Lake its mostly operations.  The work can be REALLY mundane.  Not really finance investing related work but rather just operations.  The same kind of stuff you see on a factory line.  (clip, snap, stamp, clip, snap, stamp, clip, snap stamp).  Thats about it.

job_title: Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Benefits, health ins. is second to none in the private sector. Work/life balance good. People are talented and generally intelligent. Pay is pretty good for Salt Lake, bonus can be good depends on how the company does as a whole.
cons: Mandatory 50 hour work week, over 40 hours=no overtime. Discretionary bonus calculated by a nebulus formula that NOBODY (not even top management) can really explain. Some may complain about the "low" pay but come on people this is Salt Lake, if you want big $ don't choose ops, go to New York and work in IBD, you'll have lots of money...oh yeah you'll also most likely still be single or divorced and your kids will resent you for giving your life to GS.

review_title: Amazing and prestigious firm but not a place to be if you don't know what you want
pros: Great brand name, success driven, flat structure and exposure to industry veterans. It is a great place to work if you know what you want. People are in general very bright and professional.
cons:
Little perks, average pay, long hours, too "collaborative" and too much red tape (compliance, legal, sign-off, committees... you get the point). Difficult to get things done and unfortunately not as commercial as one would think.

Due to the stressful environment, high workload and lack of training it can be difficult to get good at what you do. Production line rather than a place for learning.

job_title: Operations Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The people are smart, driven and flexible. People will rally around an issue and all will help to find the best solution. If raised your managers will work with you if you have any issues outside of work.
cons: Unrealistic expectations cause burnout. Many people can become overwhelmed by the amount of tasks you are given to do. In as competitive of an environment that Goldman Sachs is just being great at what you are asked to do puts you on the same level as everyone else. You really need to push hard to be noticed and the rewards downy always seem to match the effort.

review_title: Great company to work for, consistently attracts top talent!
pros:
-Overall recognition (by peers, family, other employers) that you work for one of the top companies in the world
-Best benefits package I've ever received
-Excellent coworkers that share a strong desire to succeed. You will be challenged at GS, but will be seen and appropriately rewarded for your efforts by senior management
-Strong ability for promotion and growth based on your performance
-Ongoing training programs are great, they also offer tuition reimbursement
-Chance to work with many divisions, even internationally
cons:
-Long hours, which is to be expected at a large investment bank
-Takes longer to have ideas implemented as they are a large company with many moving parts
-Can take a while to learn the various divisions, to see where you fit in and where you want to go next

review_title: Excellent people to work with but indifferent administration at the top (Bengaluru IBD)
pros:
- Lot of learning as you are surrounded by a extremely smart set of people
- People push you for the highest quality of work
cons:
- Very very long hours (17-18 hours a day)
- Bangalore role is a mid office role - so exit options are not that great
- Top management doesn't care about career growth for Bangalore analysts

review_title: Stay away if you want to learn
pros:
few good policies.
very good wellness/medical center.
good for freshers joining from campus placement
cons:
A lot of teams work mostly on proprietary stuff and get limited to no exposure in open source/hot technologies which makes people waste for outside market, and one fine day you realize that you are good only for GS.
Some of the managers in bangalore office are good for nothing, most of them probably came from some of the service based companies and carrying the same mindset here in GS. 
No work life balance. ( and the worst part is you end up doing a lot of crap work most of the times)
Open discrimination when it comes to NAPAs (campus hires) and lateral hires and they do it proudly. finding NAPAs getting paid more than a 3 to 10 years of lateral hires is a quite common (please sell your soul if you are planning to join as lateral hire here) , also NAPAs have a separate career growth/year end bonuses altogether.

job_title: Risk/Compliance in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The company has unmatched benefits such as the 401k contributions, excellent healthcare (not so excellent any longer), dental, vision, and fitness reimbursement.
cons: The work life balance is seriously lacking  You will find most do not take lunches or breaks.  The appearance of working long hours is the critical function, not contribution (which is unfortunate).  There is a  lack of interest in experience and talented people.  Salt Lake City is treated like a common everyday processing center without the consideration of treating their talent like human beings.

review_title: You will put in time, but it's worth it
job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Speaking from the perspective of an IB analyst, the quality and quantity of experience and  knowledge you will gain is tremendous. You will have the opportunity to work on complex and landmark transactions that have significant and long-lasting impact for the clients. Exit opportunities are excellent.
cons: Not an enviable work life balance. As an analyst or associate, working 80+ hours a week is fairly common and you will be expected to be on call and available almost all the time, including during the weekends.

review_title: Excellent place to start a career
pros: You're surrounded by really high achieving people in a professional environment. You'll work hard with the opportunity to learn with some incredibly smart people. The GS name provides an unbeatable resume boost, and the firm as a whole  is very well managed from the very top (from the perspective of benefits, events, etc.).
cons: All around great experience but not without some gripes (entirely preventable with better/more focused management at the group level). My group had some serious cultural issues that were largely ignored by the partners, who made no effort to invest behind the junior people. review_title: Its not worth risking your career by working at Goldman
pros:
- The brand name and the perceived superiority of the firm over its competitors
- The compensation (for fresh graduates) and the promotion prospects (only if the management personally likes you)
cons:
- OFFICE POLITICS : This the single biggest downside of working for Goldman Sachs. Unlike other firms, here, politics can completely ruin your career because the entire compensation structure is determined solely by your Managers opinion or by the opinion of a a Manager abroad. In the 360 degree feedback, even if your colleagues rate you highly, your manager has the right to reject their review and provide his own opinion, good or bad.  Also, small issues, like providing an opinion contrary to what your manager thinks. will ensure that you get 0 bonus no matter the work you have put in through the year. If the Manager or a foreigner likes a mediocre personality, he will get a huge bonus  no matter the pathetic performance he puts in during the year.
- NO CAREER PATH WHATSOEVER : Have you ever heard of a firm where a person with only two years experience at the firm will be the manager of a person with over five years experience in the firm, inspite of the SENIOR person being the better performer. Welcome to Goldman Sachs ..
   The firms line that it is a meritocracy, is nonsense. We have good performers and people with excellent leadership potential languishing as analysts, while their peers who have a good rapport with the foreign  managers will already be Vice Presidents. In short "apple polishing" pays out here.
Have you heard of a situation where a 23 graduate who has been trained by a 28 post graduate, ends up becoming his boss (with much higher salary of course) only because the firm is desperate to attract fresh graduates to do their no talent work. Once again, welcome to Goldman Sachs. 
In short if the management or the foreign dudes like you, your career + money + bonus are assured.
-TOO MANY PHIRANGS - The firm does not trust the work done by the Indians, which is why they send Foreigners to Bangalore by the planeload. Abroad these people are mere graduates with negligible work ex, but here they become Senior Management, who stay in high end service apartments and five star hotels with unlimited vacation time.
- NO HIGHEND WORK EVER COMING TO INDIA - The firm is nothing but a receptacle for the low end jobs that the guys out there do not want to do. When the same job is being done abroad, the work will be so low end that it will be something that an intern from college will do for the first week in order to keep in busy. Once it comes to India, it becomes hyped up, made out as if its critical with performance metrics etc but the fact is the work is still something that a 15 year old kid can probably do without much trouble. 
- DISCRIMINATION - Welcome to Goldman Sachs - Nothing is ever fair here. I am not talking about that between Indians and foreigners.  This is discrimination between you and the fellow sitting in the next cubicle. For eg, You are a performer with excellent rating who will be slogging for years without a promotion but the fellow (mediocre chap who cannot even type an e mail properly)  next to you will flying abroad every month, enjoy huge bonuses etc only because someone in the management likes him. You will suffering coming in the office cab, while this guy will driving in with the latest highend car bought with a quarter of his bonus.

In short,  this is a good place to work if you are a fresh graduate recruited from campus, but if you are a lateral hire joining from some other company, please think four times before you join. The company will only treat you like a fool and not offer you the growth that you hoped for when you left your old firm. Please do not get taken in by the compensation. Its a trick. One day the campus graduate will be your boss even is he is twenty years younger than you.

review_title: Career platform still as good as ever
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
I've been at GS since well before the firm went public in 1999.  Over that span of time its culture has remained remarkably strong and enduring.  Indeed, although there have clearly been ups and downs along the way, all the primary reasons for starting and building a career at GS remain just as relevant today as they have been for years.  Namely:

1. Strong culture of teamwork and collaboration.  People help each other out.  There is a significant focus on helping people succeed, and on nurturing and developing talent. This, in turn, drives some important aspects of the interviewing and hiring process.   Conceit is the enemy of collaboration.  If you are too convinced of the veracity of your own point of view, you will tend to undermine he team-oriented environment and the objective of getting to the best outcome on any given issue or decision. Therefore, a healthy measure of humility, balanced with a proper level of self-assurance, are key traits for successful candidates.

2. Training and Professional Development.  GS has a very extensive range of formal training offerings, although in this regard it does not differ materially from other large, leading organizations.  The more important element - and the one that will tend to play a much more relevant role in your career advancement - is the wider culture of coaching, mentorship and apprenticeship that exists in the firm.  It is a central element of the way GS works that people take an interest in teaching and developing those beneath them,  or even in other areas to whom they have only tangential connections.  While there are formal mentoring programs for summer interns and new permanent hires, the more enduring mentoring relationship are the ones that grow informally - and GS is very fertile ground for this.  Although the firm is now over 30,000 people, it retains the feel and intimacy of a much smaller firm.

3. Long term career platform.  I've worked in multiple divisions and regions with the firm.  Most managers' initial instincts are to fill open roles with talent already under the firm's roof.  Generally speaking,hiring is on such a scale that there is plenty of need to hire new people from outside the firm. However, the central point is that as an employee, you have access to a very wide variety of opportunities within GS and most people who've been at the firm for any length of time have typically been in a number of different roles or have moved around geographically.  Does it work perfectly? No - but an unusual effort is made at all times to get the right people into the right seats.  

4. Working with the best.  There really are some remarkable people at GS.  In many cases, people you work with are the most renowned at what they do in the world.  It will take your game to a new level.  I've worked personally with hundreds of GS people over time, in all kinds of functions and all kinds of places.  Contrary to popular external perception, the people are friendly and the atmosphere collegial.  While remarkably talented, people are also remarkably normal.  The kinds of people you would be pleased to have a beer with.
cons:
The firm is generally very thinly staffed.  When it works well, it provides for a rich and intense experience, rapid learning, great advancement in exposure and responsibility, and fewer people among whom to carve up the spoils. Rapid career advancement is more possible here than at many other places for this same reason.  When it does not work well, people are simply asked to do more than they are able to, which can lead to reduced morale and engagement.  The kinds of people hired by GS are those who strive for excellence.  When they are in such a position as to limit what they can accomplish to the merely ordinary, the drag on morale can be significant.

Although this aspect has improved over time, the firm still has a tendency to keep certain long-tenured senior managers for several years beyond their expiration date - well beyond the point where their contribution is particularly meaningful or positive.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY

job_title: Engineer in Salt Lake City, UT

Nice co-workers.

Tech salaries are about 10-20% below market.
