The best you  can hope for is a neutral "ok, you can keep your job today."
Highly political.
Fear is the key motivator.
High turn-over. Guaranteed layoffs every year of the lowest performing 5-10%.
Mgmt not worried about turn-over because they heavily recruit new blood from universities.

review_title: Frustrating experience as a software engineer in Ops Technology
job_title: Senior Analyst Developer in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
- Plenty of growth potential (when the market is up)
- Competitive pay (when the market is up)
- Some very smart peers
- Exposure to people working in GS offices in almost all developed and many developing countries
cons:
- Politics, politics, politics
- Bad reputation in the world - e.g. regulatory, press, general reputation amongst people.
- The amount of red tape is astounding
- Very non-competitive pay in down years (essentially everybody took a large pay cut and many took a 20% or more 2011--no, that is not an exaggeration)
- In most groups within Ops Technology, software engineering and tech in general are very much a second-class citizen to banking and trading and it shows in the way the groups are treated.
- Long hours and very poor work-life balance.  Wide-spread acceptance of this as the standard operating procedure.  If people complain (and one needs to be careful to whom you complain), the typical response is something along the lines of "this is Goldman Sachs."
- That said, there are some very, very talented software engineers at GS (including and especially the CTO, who is on the board of the Java programming language).  But broadly speaking Ops Technology is not a very talented group.  Many of the very talented people are leaving, making things worse.
- The way layoffs are handled is very much without integrity.  When I first started with every person who was let go -- either fired or laid off for some reason -- there was an announcement and an explanation.  In 2011 there were so many rounds of layoffs (at least 3 major ones, and several smaller ones) management simply acted like nothing happened.  You might be in the middle of a project with somebody and send them an email only to get what we've jokingly started calling "The Layoff Autoreply" -- their mailbox is "full".  Invariably mailbox full meant it'd been disabled and the person was laid off.  No word from management.  Just an empty desk and bounced emails.  Asking a manager for details about so-and-so would only get a "yes" or "no" to the question of whether they still worked at the firm--no details, explanation, etc. so lower and middle management had clearly been instructed not to discuss in any detail.  So it ends up just ominous chatter and gossip about who is the most recent person to be laid off.  One can imagine what this does for morale...
- Steady trickle of technology jobs -- not just support roles, but real software engineering -- out of NYC to Salt Lake City or Bangalore.  They're euphemistically called "high value locations" in GS lingo.
- Production support at night and on weekends is very widespread.  It can easily ruin a weekend.  This is fine, but coupled with the machismo "This is Goldman Sachs" mentality, it means there's no comp time and frequently not even a "thanks" for sacrificing the weekend.
- A culture that encourages distractions.  Focusing on one thing for an extended period is very, very difficult.  The cubefarm is very loud -- you need noise cancelling headphones if you're easily distracted by loud chatter or phone calls nearby.
- Dated technology is very common.  I came to GS a few years ago expecting it to be a cutting edge place, but discovered my group had just switched to Java 5--in 2009!
- Budget cuts are brutal.  There's no more travel.  No more firm sponsored happy hours.  No Blackberries unless absolutely necessary.  There are zero perks now.
- There is currently (first / second quarter 2012) an exodus from Technology at GS -- the talented people are leaving for startups, tech firms, or hedge funds.  Google is the number one firm snatching up talent from GS, but there are many, many startups doing so too.

pros: Amazing technology,  Great learning, Great brand, Great training , Great facility, Great flexibility, You can even set up meeting and talk with managers at any level.

Timings are long are not very convenient. review_title: Standard large company plus a little bit of rep

My first group was with a group of very (not necessarily relaxed, but certainly not uptight) people. Great colleagues, smart, motivated. Interesting work, if you're into that sort of thing (I was in Technology).

review_title: Lots of energy, not much direction
job_title: Software Developer in Salt Lake City, UT

job_title: Associate in Salt Lake City, UT

Technology. This company is so obsessed with protecting against a bad employee doing something stupid it's smothering. Tons of legitimate web sites are blocked, the browser has so many other restrictions it barely works, you can't send an email attachment without being interrogated multiple times, all emails and IMs constantly monitored...

Also, in SLC there aren't enough bathrooms. It sounds trivial but it's not. They cram too many people in a building and you have to hunt on sometimes 5 different floors for a stall. They said they new building would mitigate this but it didn't.

review_title: By far this has been the best group of people I have ever worked with. Great experience thus far.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY

I was able to be open about how I truly felt during the internship, and everyone gave me an intelligible and beneficial response, even if it was discussing moving divisions or to another company. In addition, GS has moved to a more merit-based promotion structure, so it'll be easier for those who excel among the best to push ahead. Nobody will micromanage you.

As a disclaimer I must say a lot depends on your group, manager and the business you support.
cons: Always need to be ahead of the game. Can get stressful, but if you can handle it, this is the place to be.

review_title: Goldman Sachs is a good place  to work.

They include excellent vacation time and consideration for different types of leave that do not effect your vacation time.  Health benefits, although employee must contribute, are very good and different levels of coverage are offered. job_title: Summer Analyst in New York, NY

review_title: Smart People, Stressful Culture, Work-life balance not very good
job_title: Internal Audit Associate in New York, NY
pros:
Very intelligent people.
If you want to learn the world of finance, there is no better place.
Awesome resume builder for anyone wanting to make a career out of finance.
cons:
Work-life is very skewed towards work.  Even in supporting offices, leaving before 6 pm is an unwritten taboo.
A lot of unnecessary stress over unimportant details.
Intimidating to ask questions of front line managers.  They are so busy they don't take the time to train new employees and expect people to just "get it" with little direction.
Pay is good, but cost of living (for NY office anyway) is ridiculous.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Parsippany, NJ
pros:
-  Practical financial work that one can apply to their own life (taxes, retirement planning, cash flow planning, etc.)

-  A decent first job out of undergrad (assuming you graduated from a non-target undergrad where Goldman, McKinsey, hedge funds, Google, etc. do NOT recruit).    

-  Ayco is a wholly owned subsidiary of Goldman Sachs, so you get the name on your resume with some benefits (employee discounts, etc.).  Ayco employees can be found in the Goldman Sachs internal employee directory, and a lot of you're employment paperwork is on GS letterhead, so I guess they're technically GS employees.  

-  Can be a great experience, but it all depends on who's team you're placed on.  If you work under a VP who's understanding and compassionate about the well-being of others, then you'll have an okay time and might even enjoy yourself.  I'd say I had a good time.

-  Ultimately, wealth management is a sales job (depends on person if a pro or con).  If you make it to VP, be prepared to be a salesman.  However, you're pretty much handed rich clients, rather than cold-calling, so that's one thing really good about Ayco.  The hard part is making it to VP.  If the business is there, then you'll be rolling in the dough as a VP (but probably traveling and working a lot as well).
cons:
-  If placed on a team with a "grinding" VP, be prepared to hate your life.  You'll literally get called on holidays and asked to come into the office.  An analyst in my office was called into work on Mother's Day while he was out with his family, and he was an hour and a half away from the office.  Also, if you plan on moving up to the VP level, you're expected to come in before your superiors and leave after your superiors (which is understandable, especially in a "face-time" focused industry like finance).  You're also expected to say "yes" to anything asked of you, including the anecdote mentioned above.  Office politics is heavy; there's a lot of brown-nosing and kissing up.  However, office politics is probably true of any work environment, especially finance;  so everyone on Glassdoor complaining about how the politics suck at Ayco should stop complaining and grow up.  Social politics is a part of life. 

-  For a wealth management firm, Ayco places an unreasonable amount of time into the tax planning and tax return preparation of clients.  If you're in the Financial Counseling division, I'd say that 75% of the work you do is tax related.  The job is not as investment heavy as it is played out to be.  As an analyst right out of undergrad (no CPA or any prior tax experience), you'll be preparing ultra complex tax returns for clients that involve multi-state sourcing of stock options and restricted stock grants, foreign income and foreign tax credits, etc.  In addition, a good number of associates in the "tax department" do not even have a CPA, nor do the VPs.  Pretty much, you'll be doing CPA level work for cheap.  I don't understand why Ayco places so much emphasis on taxes; I don't believe it adds much value to the bottom line of the firm.  If the wealth management divisions of Bulge Bracket Banks (Goldman Sachs [the REAL one], UBS, Morgan Stanley) are thriving with major AUM, have healthy profit margins, and aren't focusing on preparing tax returns, I do not buy the argument that Ayco makes that doing taxes "keeps us closer to our clients."  Instead of spending so much time and emphasis on taxes, Ayco can spend more time on bringing in new business and AUM.  I'm open to other arguments.

-  The pay is extremely low for the amount of work you're expected to do.  You'll pretty much work Wall Street hours for 1/5th of the Wall Street analyst pay, and you won't have the exit opportunities that they have.

-  Morale is extremely low.  Every analyst who isn't trying to make VP (I'd say about 80% aren't trying to make VP) is pretty much fed up after 1 year and start looking for a new job.  However, it's frustrating because wealth management skills don't really transfer to any other industry besides wealth management.  I'd say the low morale is a result of the low pay, corporate culture, and lack of employee perks compared to other companies (I hear of a lot of places that serve free lunch everyday and give every other Friday off).

-  SORRY FOR ANY GRAMMATICAL/SPELLING ERRORS.  I KNOW ANYONE WHO DISAGREES WITH WHAT I HAVE SAID WILL PROBABLY TRY TO USE MY GRAMMAR AS AN AD HOMINEM.  NOT HERE TO WRITE AN ACADEMIC ESSAY, JUST GET MY POINTS ACROSS.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The people are amazing.  Everyone cares about their work and colleagues are always willing to help each other out.  It is definitely a team environment.   Individuals are given a lot of responsibility right off the start.  Diversity is extremely important and the working environment is open and collaborative.  There are continuous training sessions and very interesting speaker events.

While all jobs usually have mundane aspects to them, the balance in Operations is probably about 80% mundane to 20% intellectual, and it should be the opposite.  This of course depends on the team you work on.

review_title: Goldman is a great place to work as an Analyst Developer if you're smart and hard-working.
pros: Career development, professional growth.  You get great experience and gain a lot of confidence working for Goldman.  You get great exposure to the financial industry, as well as cutting-edge trading technology.  You work long hours, but management is flexible as far as taking time off and leaving the office a little early, etc.  Salary is pretty good as well, but not as exceptional as most people think.
cons: Long hours, lots of work, pressure, deadlines.  You also get the feeling that compensation is not distributed fairly enough, like it's based more on popularity and politics than contributions.

review_title: great place to work, full of smiling sharks
pros: smart peers, team effort. seems to have more emphasis on product and process than style than other banks teams. everyone's discipline and commitment is inspiring, (almost) makes the long hours a little easier.
cons: never ending workload, but that is true of any other place as well. truly a huge emphasis on culture, which can be a good thing or bad thing depending on your personality. full of sharks though - more rife with office politics than other places, but hidden quite well. they almost seem to look for this in interview process/etc. as a differentiating factor.

review_title: Very materialistic place to work for where all one cares about is the bottom line....
pros: Great name on a resume, encountered some really brilliant people throughout my stay there, and learned what Corporate America is truly all about.
cons: As stated in the title, people worry more about the shoe they wear then actually investing in one's carreer. This is a geat place to start off at or even gain experience to move on to your next role, but everyone in our division from the more juinior VP's downwards to Analysts were generally dissapointed with pay, morale, and expectations put upon us.

job_title: Java/JEE Senior Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
When you say the name "Goldman Sachs", people say Wow you work for The Goldman Sachs.Lots of market value.
They work on some of the latest technologies.
Relaxed dress code on Fridays and in Jersey office - great move by a company like GS.
Free admission to museums.
cons:
Dress code is very strict, developers need to maintain dress code even if they do not interact with business for years.
WFH is a taboo.
you sitting in your desk at 7 am means a lot. Does not matter how hard you work.
Open layout is good but no phone rooms, or sofas or other areas when you want to concentrate on something. Some people think the stuff they are doing is more important and do not hesitate to scream on phone.
Food is bad and expensive.

review_title: Probably not the place to be if you're a techie. Network is top notch
job_title: Technology Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Excellent place to network. Open floor seating, although offices for higher uppers still exist. Super flexible work from home policies (at least for the tech division). ~18 days vacation plus US holidays to start off. 
For tech, highly underpaid, at least for people just starting off in their careers. 
Fun training program for new tech hires out of college.
cons:
SLOW. Of course, highly dependent on the team. 
Technology can be antiquated (lots of legacy systems).
Can be a real pain to get your hands on new tools. Many times you need permission to download new tools. 
Super bureaucratic.
Promotions seem to be based more on "connections."

review_title: Great people, great culture, hits more than it misses
pros:
- Great people: you will work with incredibly bright and knowledgeable people.
- Great culture: team work is emphasised and ingrained in the culture, so there will always be people willing to help you. Also boasts a fairly flat structure which respects and values the input of all employees not matter how junior.
- Decent pension scheme and benefits: 11% of base salary without making contributions, private healthcare, onsite gym (great value!). 
- Opportunities to keep learning: great online platform with various lessons and tutorials to keep learning throughout your career. GS also hosts great talks with influential individuals across the world, another great learning opportunity.
cons: - GS always feels understaffed meaning the hours tend to be very long and the employees tend to be very stretched.

review_title: Goldman Sachs still has room to grow in people management
job_title: Operations Technical Specialist in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
Employees at GS are compensated well. If you are not it probabaly means you are on your way out. 
The Reputation of GS is unmatached. You are sure to be the best in your field and market.
Benefits - Good 401K plan and vacation time.
Global Company - Therefore you can be mobile.
cons:
Very little personal life. The hours are daunting at times. In a crisis situation you can work around the clock.
Extremely Competitve. you must constantly try to do better than your peers and improve on your current ability overall. 
Not a good signles market. Not a company that is young in terms of age. Although there seems to be a transistion to employ more younger age employees.

review_title: Be prepared to work, even as an intern
job_title: Summer Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- Compensation
- Responsibility given to each employee
- Great training
- Perks (free dinner after 8 PM, free car after 10 PM)
- Prestige of having the firm on your resume
cons:
- The hours - even in the Operations division (where I interned), there is virtually no work/life balance
- Too much time is spent focused on tiny details that don't matter very much or at all
- Too much time spent in meetings which have nothing to do with your job
- HCM doesn't do things when they promise they will
- As is the case with any job, some managers (like the one I had) can be quite difficult to deal with

pros: Work with smart and motivated people. Great culture. Decent benefits. Steep learning curve (but only at first). Great name to put on your resume and a good place to start a career.
cons: Working in Operations means repetitive work and you are under-appreciated. Low salary/bonus for long hours and the cost of living in NYC metro area. Purposely limited mobility to other divisions. Comp and promotions do not seem merit based and take longer than other divisions.

pros: You work with some really great people at GS. I met some of my best friends at this place, and even after we moved on to other jobs we have remained close friends. The building is also incredibly cool and you feel proud to come to work every day.
cons: Work life balance in some positions can be pretty rough, but you should know this already if you're looking to get into any Finance based role.

review_title: Great name to have on resume
job_title: Equity Research Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
I worked as an equity research analyst at GS. 

The firm is a highly recognizable name even when compared together with other wall street investment banks. Even if you work there for a couple of years, it opens the door for many more opportunities. 

Great training. Great platform. Great benefits (incl. healthcare, gym, meal allowances etc).
cons: Career path is not as straight forward for equity analysts as compared to investment banking analysts. One is pretty much dependent on his lead analyst to leave to be promoted to the senior role.

pros: Lots of smart people and lots of opportunity to have a varied career in a location that is not New York. Lots of mobility opportunities
cons:
1) Low revenue and cost cutting has given rise to horrible office politics, lack of transparency into strategy and a lot of finger pointing when things go bad.
2) For junior level VP's there is little or no coaching opportunity. You are practically left to you own devices and blamed squarely for any mistakes.
3) Brutal hours and little or no work life flexibility. A lot of senior managers set a bad example by sending e-mails over the weekend and you are viewed unfavorably if you don't respond.

review_title: Great learning experience in S&T but hard work
pros: Great people. You get a lot of responsibility quickly, and the hierarchy is very meritocratic so you do not feel held back. You also get job offers from competitors and other companies rather quickly.
cons:
Very stressful, seems like the workload is higher than in other banks. All the desks on the trading floor are permanently short staffed so the hours are longer, but the salary is (or should be at least) higher.

One thing that annoyed my seniors and discouraged juniors, myself included, was that lateral hires got significantly better salaries than homegrown talent. That doesn't really inspire juniors or promote loyalty. Short term thinking.

review_title: Fantastic Place To Start A Career
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Working in the finance department is a good place to learn how to operate in a large company with multiple divisions. If you work hard you will receive significant responsibility. 
Internal mobility is difficult but possible, if you work hard and network you can move across divisions.
cons:
Work tends to be process based rather than true problem solving. 
The company is large and therefore has its fair share of politics.
There is a significant push for diversity, which I believe is important, but the effort has come at the cost of hiring less qualified candidates.
Face time still exists, there is shaming for leaving earlier than others even if there is no more work to be done.

review_title: GS- a great place to work, at least in the short term...
pros: Challenging environment, intelligent competent people, best training in its class, great opportunities for career advancement and professional growth, great compensation, great on the resume for business school and other career opportunities. The 360 performance review process can be helpful, but you must stay aggressive about managing your career and where you want to go professionally in order to stand out amongst your peers and challenge yourself. There are also a lot of opportunities for advancement if you're great at networking. Otherwise, you can get stuck in a division or job role that you may not like.
cons: politics, lack of communication b/w management and employees, sometimes ppl are too high strung

review_title: The Salt Lake office will always be a second-tier location
job_title: Vice President in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Goldman Sachs brought a lot of new developer job openings to Utah, and those positions do not require deep technical knowledge. People who transfer to Salt Lake from New York are likely to be exposed to good career opportunities.
cons: For people who are comfortable with computer science, Goldman Sachs doesn't have any advanced technical positions. The 80-100 hour weeks that I gave and the great performance reviews did not help me get closer to a promotion. The problem is that nothing produced in Salt Lake City generates any revenue, so it's the last place that rewards would be given. The company aims to hire more expendable entry-level developers, and neglects its experienced workers, because that is the most certain way to keep costs low.

job_title: Summer Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The pay is enormous. Pay is almost 120k as a analyst. Your work hard and you receive heavy savings. The perfect place for a workaholic
cons: You have to manage your time.Your work 100 hours minimum....This is not a place where you want to stay permanently.

pros:
1) Brilliant minds working with you.
2) Process oriented (at least tries to)
3) Good code reviews in place.
4) Latest technologies(varies from team to team, will comment further)
5) Decent Pay (During joining, not great but OK)
cons:
1) Dirty politics in India
2) Local Management tries to dominate over tech folks, and prefers dumbos!
3) No Clarity on promotions/hikes. Worst part is people who have joined with experience and cleared all their 6-7 rounds of interview are paid way way less than freshers.
4) Feel like non technical person if you are stuck in few teams ,where work is nothing but database INSERTS/DELETES/UPDATES.
5) More of YES BOSS attitude is preferred.

pros: Very professional and a great name on a resume. You are working with some of the most intelligent people all in the same room. Very busy and will learn quickly.
cons: This company feeds off the young employees. They have shortened their hours but completely understand that they still put in over 50 hrs a week. Also, they are a little cocky. They believe that they are the big fish and you are lucky to be with them. Like I said, not for everyone. They only hire those that are humble, smart, and don't like to spend time outside of work.

review_title: Great experience, great company, phenomenal peers
pros: The name on your resume is second to none. They also provide a ton of benefits outside typical health and retirement. They provide free web based employee training on hundreds of topics, Sponsored by names like Fitch Learning, Investment Banking Institute, Wall Street Prep, and other platforms that would other cost hundreds/thousands of dollars.
cons: The office is are stilled fairly ruled by office politics. Meritocracy is definitely present, though; if you make a name for yourself and impress upper levels, you will definitely be rewarded.

pros: Great benefits, generous PTO, looks good on the resume.
cons: The culture is within Marcus is very toxic and political. Management only focuses on people who kiss up to them, you only get ahead by management liking you, rather than the results you get. The pay is below market value. The culture is that you work ridiculous hours or you are considered lazy. Everyone is there to get ahead even if it means throwing someone else under the bus. Change is horribly communicated, you are expected to fall in line and not ask questions.

review_title: Goldman Sachs - A great place to work
pros: I work with some of the smartest people in the world.  Everyone is 100% dedicated at GS.  Additionally, the level of communication is outstanding with everyone knowing what's going on at any one time.  We tend to have a lot of meetings which can be viewed as negative (analysis paralysis some might say), but I find it very helpful.  Everyone gets involved in the approval process this way, and everyone's voice is heard.  The flattened hierarchy at GS avoids all the beauracracy and people can get down to work without worrying about the "proper" chain of command.  And lastly, the technical systems that have been built by in-house GS personnel are some of the most advanced and useful pieces of software in the industry.
cons: Nothing really important that would warrant a comment.

pros: Flexibilility in time off.  No limits on the time you take (i.e. 3 times in a 3 month period, then you are written up).  Noone asks why you are taking the time.  Training is top notch and the name will open doors for you.  Advnacement is touted, but you really have to earn it.
cons: They are quick to lay off.  Your really have to prove yourself.  They are extremely task oriented, but ate the same time there is alot of favoritism and if you are not within the clique, then you have limited potential.

review_title: Its an amazing first place to work right out of college
job_title: Technology Analyst in New York, NY
pros: There is a reason why Goldman Sachs is called the best on the street. The people you work with are Type A, first class and most likely always the smartest people you ever met. I learned about discipline and professionalism working there.
cons: Work life balance was poor. Being the best on the street is not a substitute for paying people what they deserve. Technology should not be looked at as a cost center as it is the fuel that drives all operations on wall street and the technologists at Goldman should not be treated like second class citizens as they have built some of the most sophisticated and complex trading and analytics platforms in the world of finance.

pros: They sorely need techs who are rational and pragmatic and can lead the inexperienced pool of convertd interns. I can easily outperform peers. Although the marginal benefits of outperformance is low. In fact, the outperforming person gets leeched on by users, peers and managers who relegate their responsibilities, you need to learn to stop working and go home. The only outcome is that the chance of being laid off is low.
cons:
Vicious and political corporate culture, pursue culture of treating individual as commodity, while the "system" is first class citizen.
Talk of impact oriented, meritocratic culture is just corporate, marketing speak, far from reality.
Annual culling of "low performing" employees frequently causes people to be politically oriented
Non trading, non operations functions are really detached from the real businesses, have limited financial markets knowledge. Not much to learn from.

pros: I cant really think of any.. If your lucky to be in a humane team of people you definitely have career growth provided your good at office politics. oh yes you need to know how to party late into the night if you want to grow.
cons: The management is  really happy with the bunch of freshers they recruit  from colleges who are willing to stay on for years, these are a bunch who don't know the outside corporate world and don't know the meaning of teamwork and try to shun any outside recruits with their bad attitude.

review_title: Hard to stay around long term
pros: Able to receive global perspective and work with diverse workforce. Plenty of opportunities if you are driven. 360 degrees performance review, usually pretty objective. "Flat" structure compared to most bulge bracket banks. Reputation is still outstanding enough in the industry that you'll have no problem finding a good job after working here.
cons: Long working hours on tedious and mundane tasks. Really bad morale. People usually don't stay around for more than two years. Compensation does not reflect the amount of work put in. Always cutting costs. Senior management often "preaches" culture and lack transparency.

review_title: Good Opportunity for entry level but leave as soon as you get licensed
pros: Putting Goldman on your resume. This is literally the only benefit you will get from this company.
cons: There is more pressure than you can believe. Pressure to not take vacation. Pressure to get all the work done and not work overtime. Some employees will work overtime and not clock it all because it is so frowned upon. Leadership is terrible in creating opportunities for motivated candidates. They suppress those that are willing to lead. They re-branded the company trying to establish they have changed but this is certainly not the case. The selection process for advancement is for those willing to never say a word or give input. If you do not speak then you will be promoted. Pay is well below the value you will add and the uncertainty for the job makes it just that much worse.

review_title: Great place to work but a bit behind the times on technology
pros:
- Great group of people to work with, which is helpful given the extensive hours
- Lot of internal mobility options if you tire of the same role and would like to try something different; often easier interview process relative to external hires making it easy to join in a federation role and transition to a client facing role
cons:
- This has been said in numerous reviews but the hours can be incredibly challenging At times.
- Even in client facing roles “pet projects” and unecesary bureaucracy can add to the burden and become frustrating
- Technology is outdated with a lot of computationally heavy work being done in Excel.

review_title: Legacy Code Base, Loaded with Technical Debt

The bonus comp structure, and uncertainty surrounding it, is used by management to underpay employees. I was paid 15% under-market during my time there, using this underhanded negotiating tool.

'diversity' has created Cultural/Caste system issues, and language barriers throughout Tech. If you think IT people are poor explainers, wait until you have to understand the system via broken English.

pros: No Pros for this company

review_title: Goldman Sachs: Industry-wide leader in technology
job_title: Technology Analyst in Jersey City, NJ
pros: It's a very flat organization that treats its employees well. The culture is great too. Almost all decisions are made through consensus. Also, they value technology heavily. The firm attempts to use proprietary technology to gain a competitive advantage over other banks. Therefore, unlike other banks, Goldman Sachs' Technology Division is very large and very respected. Furthermore, the people you will meet are absolutely brilliant. It's really been a pleasure working for a place like Goldman Sachs. I was an intern last summer and I look forward to returning as a full-time employee.
cons: Its a great company to work for but the hours are extremely long. I really can't think of any other weaknesses; I've thoroughly enjoyed my time here at Goldman.

job_title: Vice President, Human Capital Management in New York, NY
pros: The intensity, drive and commitment of people who work at GS is impressive, and amongst "producing" divisions, the intelligence, commercial drive, and decision-making ability of senior leaders is unparalleled.  The firm has pockets of true meritocracy, and really does value teamwork.
cons: Human Capital Management is a division under strain - there are pockets where strategy and creativity are rewarded and true partnership with the business occurs; but for the most part, execution is rewarded above all else.  Expect to work at least 65-75 hours a week at least.  But you will get a free car home after 10pm!

review_title: Do not work for this company.
job_title: Analyst Programmer in New York, NY
pros: They give you a decent basic salary but its not worth the trouble.
cons:
That salary is the only thing you will get. If you manage to get a good salary you can bet they will most likely give you a shitty bonus instead, unless you outperform the entire department. 
This company will never ask too much of you, you will be required to work extremely long and boring hours in manage to do a decent job unless you are beyond extremely talented and most people who work here are just above average. People will try to compete with you on every level, lots of backstabbing in private conversations, everyone for their own, be careful. Its mind boggling to me why smart people stay at GS. Many people around me was burn outs having sacrified their bodies with little return. I've never been worse treated than I was at GS. I'm very happy i left.

review_title: Fantastic is the word that comes to my mind straightaway
pros: Teamwork is the hallmark of this organization. There is a very strong belief that we can always achieve more if we are working as a team as opposed to individually. There is no emphasis on star culture.
cons: Long working hours are the biggest bane of goldman sachs. It is now ingrained so much in the culture that its almost an inseparable part. Those who have to do well are always constrained for quality personal time. There is little to enjoy outside of office if you an average person but if you are a workalholic, there is no better place to work than GS.

review_title: Great Company ... but not for everyone
pros:
I worked in the Technology division for 5 years.

1. I worked in the technology division of Goldman Sachs and i admire the smart people and technical courage of the company. The company truly believes in technology and is not afraid to build (and invest) in home grown products where all financial companies just live on the mercy of vendors and system integrator. You will be surprised at the scale and complexity of technical projects executed by Goldman on their own without the involvement of any vendor or service integrator.

2. They take great pride and ownership in their work. The company outsources very little and products receive great attention from everyone. Managers pay great attention to detail. Goldman definitely seeks perfection in what they do.
cons:
1. Get used to executive worship culture. Goldman have MDs and Partners and they are living Gods in the corridors. This create a culture of sycophancy and executive pleasing. I have seen people spend their days and nights not on working but pleasing.

2. Very New York Centered.  New York is the absolute power center and the managers there will share nothing with anyone else (even with other US cities). In other cities you don't have an authority to do anything without triple New York approval.

All important projects are completely controlled out of NY and if you are in other locations you will find that its hard to grow. (or even breathe).

3. Its a company which encourages a culture where people work 20 hours a day. It's common to see colleagues work nonstop from 6:30 AM to Midnight.

4. Organizational Arrogance: Management has very firm views on what needs to be done and you have little or no voice. It takes many years of service for anyone to have a voice in the company. Questioning or disagreement almost always is a career limiting (or ending) move.

This arrogance leads to a culture where people spend their entire culture building mega personas, and hyper images of themselves. Its a culture where snobbery thrive.

5. Very rigid organizational rules: Goldman follows lots of processes and governance models around IT. These models are so rigid that even small tasks can take many months of back and forth wrangling between IT and governance teams. This is why executing even small projects takes 10 times the effort it would take in a easy going organization.

review_title: A good starter job.   A technologists view of GS.
pros: Above average pay.  Training that you won't get anywhere else on a variety of technical and nontechnical topics.  Benefits are very good.  People are smart.
cons:
In the technology division of Goldman, they have racked up tremendous technical debt.  That debt needs to be repayed and the current work reflects that.  Plan on spending a lot of time doing technical support and learning a lot of code that is not well-documented.  Plan on fixing bugs and doing a lot of "uplift" work.  If you are lucky, you may get to do some new development - but probably not for a few years.

Goldman technology has had a lot of attrition the past 2 or 3 years - people getting fed up with the status quo.  Management doesn't appear to be doing much about it.  Their new strategy seems to be to drive their senior engineers out of the organization and replace them with younger, low-cost engineers that they can work to death and hold a work visa over their heads.

Goldman hasn't had a really good year income-wise, since 2009.  When you are interviewing, they will sell the "bonus" as a significant part of your total compensation.   But, the bonus is directly related to the firms earnings for the year and less related to the great work you did that year.  You could be a super hero engineer one year, but if the firm did badly that year, plan on a small bonus.  On the other hand, you could have a less than stellar year with the firm performing well, and get a good bonus.  My experience was that I got a good bonus a couple of years and a less-than-inspiring bonus on the other years.

They talk a good talk about work-life balance, making you believe that is part of the corporate culture.  Don't believe it.  Once you get to the VP level and above, you will need to sell your soul to GS to continue to move up the corporate ladder.   If you don't care about having a life outside of work and your family is a low priority, you will do very well at GS.  Also be sure that you have very good skills playing "corporate games" and politics as you move up the ladder.  Those skills become very important.  If you are a good smoozer, you will do well.  If not, plan on being treated badly enough that you will choose to leave on your own.

Goldman rarely fires people.  Their strategy is to level off your salary and stop paying you bonuses, until you leave on your own.  It's a lot cleaner that way.  No lawsuits to worry about for wrongful firing.   GS is always looking to "manage risk", even when it comes to their people.

Finally, the most important thing.  Make sure you have a great relationshsip with your direct manager.  GS does a "360 degree review", but 350 of those degrees are the opinion of your direct manager.  Even if 15 of your peers think you are a superstar, you will not got a good ranking, if your direct manager thinks you are lacking.   By the way, a poor ranking against your peers translates into getting passed over for a bonus.

Summary -  Join GS right out of college, work 4 or 5 years, get trained, get some experience, get GS on your resume and get out.  A smart strategy for the smart engineer.

review_title: Good Overall Experience, Managers Need Work
pros: I have worked at GS for 10 years, and the level of professionalism of my colleagues is the best part of working there.  Generally very team-oriented, despite the high-caliber of self-motivated individuals that tend to work there.  Excellent benefits, salary and bonus potential.  Focus on the client and business principles are not just words on a page, the firm constantly reinforces them and demands them of each employee.  Challenging work, good internal mobility for those who perform.
cons: You are completely on your own in terms of career development and progression.  Managers are not not expected to manage their people,nor are they rated in this area in their annual performance reviews.  I was told straight out by a former manager that he was not rated on his ability to manage people who worked for him.  6 years under his management and I can confirm that is the case.  Determine what you want your career path to be, then make it known broadly that's what you want.  Your personal career development and success may not be a priority or even a concern of your direct supervisor.  Don't assume working 70-80 hours per week will get you noticed or rewarded.  You need to network and say 'No' often enough to force management to address resourcing issues or your career aspirations.  Getting everything done no matter what simply enables them avoid addressing issues within their area of concern, and take credit for keeping things running smoothly.  Managers at GS simply don't exist .... they are expected only to deliver towards the bottom-line, not to worry about the needs of their people.   It's one way of doing things, and has certainly been successful, but be aware of this fact and act accordingly.

cons: The india office is full of politics, with some managers not really upto the mark, but only staying on through politics. The pace is fast and can get you overwhelmed at times. You really need to find your way around things.

review_title: In IT, too many levels of bureaucracy.
pros: Benefits are good. Focus is on new employees. Annual new hire 'classes' (NAPAs) are hired and trained together.
cons: Far too many levels of management. Promotions predicated on a corporate structured 'to-do' list rather than on job performance. Review process is determined from the top down, forcing each employee into a predetermined number of rating slots. Company profits used to relate directly to bonus structure, but this is no longer the case.

job_title: Operations Analyst Intern in London, England
pros: I interned at Goldman Sachs from June 2015 - June 2016. I was in the Credit Flow middle office of the operations division. The culture at GS is extremely supportive and the exposure you receive to different divisions and institutions in the operations department is next to none.
cons: One of the down-sides would be the working hours. Often I had to be in hour after the traders have left.

pros: The only pro of working at this company is having the name on your resume when you leave.
cons: This company will take your soul. This was the most gruesome 3 months I ever spent at any job I've ever had. The work was mundane & the pay wasn't worth how miserable I felt every morning. I dreamed of working at this company for years, but trust me when I say the name is not work the misery. Skip this place and work for a company that cares about giving you career opportunities and your personal skill development.

review_title: Good place to experience Company Culture, but don't expect too much
pros: Benefits, Co-Curricular activities, Fitness Center, Wellness Center, Avenues to express yourself apart from your day job. Largely everything depends on your reporting manager, He/She can make your time at GS - Hell or Heaven.
cons: Disproportionate allotment of work, only being from a good school will be enough to get you everything (Comp, Bonus, Projects). Many applicable policies are not followed by managers in the true spirit. Petty office politics is sometimes also at play but largely the firm is dependent on the reporting manager to run the organization.

review_title: Great firm and culture, one of a kind
job_title: Technology Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The best people in the business. If you look hard enough, you will find very good mentors who will help in your career growth. Being around reall good people, pushes you to perform and excel. I worked in GSAM (Goldman Sachs Asset Management) where the culture is a bit different than the rest of the firm. Nonetheless, the overal theme of teamwork is the same across the board.
cons: Work and life balance is touted but never sufficiently encouraged. Politics and lack of transparency tends to shroud decision making. GSAM is particularly lacking in these respects. While the overall culture of the firm is the same, there are glaring deficiencies in GSAM.

pros: As an intern, I was given plenty of opportunities to network with senior management.  There are plenty of social events.  The salary is higher than you'd find anywhere else.  You'll work hard and you'll learn a lot.  I've found that managers are always willing to answer your questions.
cons:
You need to be willing to take initiative.  Also, interns in technology may find that their jobs are a bit repetitive.  A friend of mine spent a summer working on a code fragment of less than 500 lines.

Despite two sucessful summer internships, I was not given a job offer due to economic conditions.

review_title: If you want to go to Goldman Sachs don't come to SLC because you might as well go to India
job_title: Operations Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
The benefits are amazing. Great coverage and a good 401K match program. Working in SLC you might have an opportunity to have more of a work life  balance but it depends on the team they assign you to.
If you get on your managers good list you might get a good bonus which would bring you up to a normal salary.
cons:
SLC is an outsourced office like India is. In SLC you are a back office employee, please please don't think you are going to have an opportunity to get to the front office from SLC. People do it but it is truly 1 in 500.
Compensation is very every low because you are doing work that college kids do. If you are an experienced hire don't think about SLC because they want cheap labor which means only college kids. 
Don't expect to be doing any real financial work as this is the operations division and you only work with systems and processes.
Expect to have poor managers who don't know how to communicate like normal people. Because this is operations you don't have anybody here who is a outgoing and communicates well.
Expect you manager to do nothing. Once you are at the company 5 years you might be considered a team leader and you then get to just surf the web. 
Don't be fooled by their claim that there is a lot of growth in SLC. There is but most of it is coming in the technology division. Even if there is growth in your team they will not hesitate to bring people from NY or LDN or HK to manage. 
Remember this job is more like a support job so be ready to be treated poorly by clients as well as other GS employees from bigger offices.
Knowledge is non-existent here. Everybody tries to pass off questions to the next team because GS does not train you to know the whole picture just your one little function.

review_title: Not a bad place to work as a first job
pros:
-some of the most intelligent best people in the investment banking business
-team culture
-can be a supportive learning environment
-great name to have on the resume for any future jobs
cons:
-culture cuts both ways - can be a difficult place to work if you don't fit the established culture
-intensely political, as in IBD or very cut-throat as in certain sales or trading jobs
-revolving door means that sometimes senior people don't see the need to invest in junior people beyond the minimum needed to get a job done

pros: Coworkers treat one another with respect. The culture of Goldman Sachs is unlike any place I've ever worked. One truly feels like they could reach out to anyone for help; teamwork is constant and encouraged at every level.
cons: As with any job on Wall Street, the hours are long. But the time spent is well worthwhile as there is always plenty of work to be done and you will be rewarded for the time you put it.

review_title: Do you like working at GS? I do.
pros:
It depends on your passion, your interest and your job description, but I generally feel satisfied and proud about my work. I like my job.
There are great opportunities for career advancement at GS. You can advance in your department or move to a different departments or different locations. The firm supports intra-departmental and inter-location mobility.
You also get to work with the most passionate and 'workaholic' people. 

Compensation is very good I think...
cons: Definitely the long hours and the work pressure are the worst downside I think. Since most ppl here are smart, determined and ambitious, you need to work longer and harder, at the minimum to not appear stupid and obviously to excel.

review_title: Amazing but be prepared to work to the bone
pros:
People are indeed top rate
Firm culture is quite cohesive and suprisingly small for its size
GS is truly an elite institution with a work ethic second to none, no nonsense and focused
Pay (well this year will be a tough one)
cons:
Newcomers mostly at a disadvantage- political equity extremely important to advance career
Work to people ratio disproportionate- hence you will be pulling some very long hours, doing the work of a team of 4 anywhere else on your shoulders 
Lay offs can be brutal and sudden
Very limited time away from work- be on your blkbry always
Political sparring can get intense

pros: A good place to learn if you are a self-starter and want exposure to several roles, something that is facilitated by the huge turnover at this place.
cons:
Poor leadership especially in equiities which is effectively run by people who have have never picked a stock and make every move to promote their personal survival, often by eliminating the best investors.

The US business is already being eaten alive by passive funds and poor performance affects all parts of the business.

pros: Good income potential long term, if you can stick around . Account manager is the main position of the company’s , or only one they care about . They all make six or seven figures , but not without a long road there and continued high stress , long hours, and never ending travel
cons:
Underpaid 
Overworked 
Poor culture and company morale
Management provides zero appreciation to employees 
Expected to work well into the night and on weekends if you expect to get anywhere 
Very political , must be willing to play the corporate suck up game , good work and attitude isn’t enough

pros: Great to have on a resume and the experience and knowledge gained is invaluable. The people are great.
cons: This company doesn’t seem like what it used to be. Morale seems lower. No work life balance - even though there could be if they weren’t so cheap to invest in technology. Ayco seems more of a puppet of Goldman.

job_title: Operations Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Name brand on your resume
cons:
Don’t give a care in the world about their employees. 

They literally gave used books and thrift store items as rewards to high performers on my team and those next to us. I got a GS hat for doing the work of two people for a month. Would have preferred to have gotten nothing. 

Bonus is based on how you did compared to your peers not how well you actually did. 

Racist and sexist company. They have groups and associations for everyone and everything unless you’re white or a male or straight. 

Teammates do everything they can to crawl over you and get their name on your project so they can claim they helped lead and advise you on it. 

Managers only care about you if you’re going to help them get promoted.

pros:
-- Good compensation and benefits
-- Smart people to work with 
-- Great Senior Leadership
cons:
-- Work Life balance is non-existent; Everybody is hardpressed for time working at 150% capacity and invariably end up putting 12-14 hour days on a regular basis
-- Job insecurity; It seems like a deliberate strategy by the senior management to ensure that people give all they have to save their jobs
-- Few options to move to different roles within the organization
-- Longevity matters; Most senior positions within the organization are held by long timers. Need to invest at least 5-7 years to reach a worthy place in the organization

review_title: Experience has been overall good but difficult unless you pretend to agree with everything "Goldman"
job_title: Product Controller in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Competitive environment. In the good years, if you've performed well per your manager, bonuses are quite good. Good training and the company does push community involvement.
cons:
For the Salt Lake office specifically, management truly subscribes as SLC as a cost savings center.  Salaries are justified lower due to location, but only for those hired on in SLC versus if you transfer in from another location.
For internal mobility, some jobs can be blocked if they don't want you to move, which seems contrary to what managers say.
Review process is really only about what your manager thinks of you.

review_title: It has been a mostly positive experience.
pros: Great benefits, good pay. The offices are stylish and clean. The animal labs are state-of-the-art.
cons: Sometimes things just feel a little off. I can't put my finger on it, but I'm sure it's nothing. I did have a conflict with a superior over an ethical issue, but it was quickly resolved and I didn't have to compromise my principles - I even got a pay raise. Now I work closer with the animal labs and pens.

review_title: Bright but unprofessional people. No Work-Life balance.
pros: You will work with talented pool of people. Exposure to a wide range of software development and control processes. Good facilities like leaves, food, transport etc.
cons:
Not a professional environment to work, people ask you to write very good review and rating for them. Worst is, people ask you to write unsolicited review for them.

You should be on your toes, else you will be asked to quit. To succeed in technology department, being technically sound is optional. 

Very difficult to maintain work life balance.

Unlike other companies, too much importance to communication, visibility, diversity. 
Like any other investment banks, there is no relation between designation and compensation.

review_title: GS is the Best for a reason...
pros: Yes, GS has industry leading compensation and industry leading benefits… but what makes Goldman the premier destination for anyone interested in finance is the staff.   I was surrounded by the most driven, committed, competitive, brightest people on earth.   It's like working at NASA or the NBA or Mayo Clinic.
cons: The hours can be brutal even if you love what you do.

review_title: Nice environment but dont take new ideas easily
job_title: Senior Analyst Dev in New York, NY
pros:
Get to work with good people and some interesting projects. 
They always look to be leading edge so you can have very interesting learning experiences and insights
Managers are responsive to your desire for growth
cons:
Slow to  absorb ideas from some one newly joined - can make you feel that you are too "small"
Work environment in my team very dull /mechanical - not much fun being around in office
Though they promote internal mobility there is too much red tape and infighting over that - difficult to get to what your interest is unless you have put in the "time"

review_title: Good pay, long hours, lots of politics
job_title: Vice President in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The best things about Goldman Sachs are that they pay very well. This should be taken with a grain of salt though because the hours a longer than other industries. So, if you are offered 100k but are working 12 hour days, you would really only be making 66k at a job where the hours are normal.  They are also pretty flexible if the job can allow it.  There are people who work from home one day a week, have special schedules, etc.  the work is interesting and busy. The days go by quickly even though they are long. It seems like there is never a dull moment.  When I first started at GS 10 years ago, the work was like most entry level jobs, meaning there was a lot of repetitive day to day work. However, the work evolved over time just like any job and has become more analytical and value add.  There is a huge focus on diversity.
cons: I have 4 direct managers who have different agendas and don't communicate well with each other leaving me with multiple competing tasks.  The firm works people long hours.  There are retention problems because of work life balance. The median age is 25 because the older folks with families can't make the hours work and still spend time with their kids.  While they claim that their culture is consensus driven, it has shifted over the years to be more directive.  They also tote that their employees are a most valuable asset but don't seem concerned with giving them more personal time.  Head count reductions over the years have come with no backfill but the same amount of work.  Their perception is that you are lucky to be working there among the cream of the crop and that "it's not for everyone". Most VPs I know are looking for jobs somewhere else and are only still there because they haven't found another job.

review_title: Excellent company to work for, Great benefits.
job_title: Vice President in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Compensation, enjoyable work, cool people and freedom to choose what you want to do within reasons of course. Access to people at all levels of management without a lot of red tapes. Generous vacation package and 401K matching.
cons: Long hours, lack of work-life balance. The expectations are way above anyone else in the similar industry and almost unrealistic at a time. Forcing employees to move to an office location that is not part of employee's current demographics and hence force them to resign or get laid off.

pros: Intelligent people. Great benefits. Good salary. A lot of opportunity for growth.
cons: they hold on to some senior people that are not good culture carriers because they view them as indispensable.  if you happen to work with one of these bad eggs on your team, it changes your entire experience of the firm. i was lucky that during my tenure, 10+ years, I worked with great people up until the last year and a half. the company needs to do a better job retaining mid-level talent.  also, work-life flexibility is possible, but you have to work hard at making it a priority and expect some push back.

review_title: Too hard work, stress and pain for too little money.
pros:
People around you are smart (BUT, it will not benefit you, rather the opposite)
Offices are cool
You can pick up hot girls by showing them your business card
cons:
You will be required to work very, very, very hard (even if it sounds fun, its not). 
They will never ask too much from you. Every request should be done on time, which sometimes require you to work insane hours, even if you are ultra smart and efficient.
Your day life will be full of stress, your stomach will start to hurt and you will not be able to sleep well at nights waking up randomly screaming.

pros:
Always being encouraged to challenge yourself, and get things done better and quicker. 
Great people to work with - intelligent, fun, always willing to give up their time to help and very down to earth (despite the external reputation for being arrogant).
Management work hard to keep employees up to date on company strategy.
cons:
Long working hours, so work-life balance isn't great.  This can be especially hard as you get older and start having family commitments.
External perceptions of GS can be pretty negative.

review_title: Great name with a lot of career advancement opportunities but no work life balance.
pros:
Smart People
Good Name on Resume
Opportunity to make a difference very early in career
Great starting compensation
Dynamic working environment
cons:
No work like balance
Culture of working more hours than necessary
Anyone can be laid off, even a top performer
Focus is constantly changing, can make it difficult to get a read on management priorities
Firm is under great regulatory scrutiny

review_title: Great place if you have a strong bent for technology. Bangalore needs to still take better chunks of the IB.
pros:
If you are inclined to grow technically you have very strong options should you choose to!
It's one of the very few org's i have seen which is able to give you the option to grow into Project stream or Tech stream.. for an IB that is quite impressive.
cons:
If you are inclined to grow both functionally and technically you have little options and many units deal in back office technology. 
Work Life balance... GS is not your 'Life' ... it's the 'Work' part of your 'Life'.

pros: Benefits, locations, types of businesses, networking opportunities if you are aggressive. If you land with the right group/manager, you can go far. Ability to get assignments in other states or countries if you desire.
cons: Review system is constantly getting revamped and i don't feel they ever get it right. The need for consensus often makes getting approval or the green light extremely time consuming. Middle management is in need of training. You can easily be pigeonholed before you even know it. It is not as easy to move around within the company.

review_title: Definitely a good place to start
job_title: Technology Analyst in New York, NY
pros: This was my first job out of college so it was great meeting so many new people and making friends. Goldman definitely invests in its people and gives its new employees time to get up to speed on things. Expect a ton of training and networking events.
cons: At the end of the day, Goldman's an investment bank, and although its starting to change, technology still feels like a second tier (under the traders, banking, and finance divisions). It's not the place where you're going to come in and change the world, or help everyday people solve problems. But you'll definitely learn a lot along the way. Also, it's very team dependent. Different teams treat their employees differently.

pros: They pay for your licenses/certifications.
cons: Absolutely terrible compensation. They continually dangle the carrot in front of you with the promise of future salary and bonus increases. The salary and bonus structure is based on a convoluted algorithm that somehow shows an increase in compensation when in actuality your overall pay decreases.The hours are extremely long, and despite the high turnover rate you are expected to pick up the workload for other analyst who have left the firm. They continualy question why morale is so low, and their best remedy is to this is to offer a "jeans day" on Friday's. Ayco has relied on its upstate demographic to justify paying its employees terrible salaries, but unfortunately they are starting to see the ramifications of this via employee turnover at an alarming rate.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in London, England
pros: Decent salary, well educated and eloquent people. Great place to work in IT if you have minimal or no tech skill, but you like to talk a lot about things that should be done instead of doing them.
cons: Proprietary technology - no reusable skills. Long hours on the phone (as a software engineer) instead of development/design. Most of people never worked anywhere else - this is not because they are so good, but rather they wouldn't get a job anywhere else. Perfect GS strategy to keep employees.

job_title: Investment Professional in New York, NY
pros: You learn from a diverse group of peers who are driven and ambitious. Gain tremendous business skills such as communication, attention to detail, financial savvy, understanding of businesses and investors, and importance of sales.
cons: The hours were really tough and most of the time the job that we were doing was to help the portfolio manager get more clients. Much of the job could be quite trivial at times and not very rewarding. In addition, the pay wasn't all that great.

pros:
There are a lot of smart people who work there, you are constantly pushed to find the best in you. Also there is a lot of emphasis on generating revenue. Very meritocratic (within divisions)
Very competitive compensation
If you re very hard working and commercial there is much room for advancement. For sales and trading there are a lot of firm resources to "leverage"
cons:
Not much respect outsidde of sales and trading.
Very difficult for qualified people to move into S&T from other areas. I don't think that the downsides are any different to anywhere else. Basically when you go there be sure that you will like your group and job function, cause it's unlikely you'll be moving.

review_title: Only for extroverts and street smart people!
pros:
- Great brand value
- Above average pay
- Great learning opportunities
- Opportunities to work abroad for short period
- Flat organisation and good HR policies (appraisal, transfers, trainings, reviews, etc)
cons:
- The worst work life balance
- Work could be monotonous and really long (depends on team and division)
- Extreme competition for bonus and reviews, so gets really political
- Managers in India only network and catch-up, without any work, shouldering of responsibilities.
- Have to suck up to on-site teams to get visibility without which you perish
- Less analytical and more process oriented work
- Worst of all, no assurance of long term job security.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
- Outstanding group of high-achieving professionals who are excellent across the board
- The emphasis on teamwork is not just a tagline -- the culture really emphasizes teamwork and most people who can't play nicely with others are either coached or managed out...a culture of high-functioning teamwork across such a large corporation is truly a feat
- You'll learn a ton from some of the best in the industry
cons:
- Industry is going through challenging times, culture of innovation is now constrained
- Financial upside at the company is now more limited, will likely be harder to attract & retain top talent in future generations of employees (investment banking becomes commercial banking)

pros:
Ample opportunities to learn new things. 
Work with a lot of hard-working, bright people. 
If you're hardworking individual with plenty of personal time to spare on work, you can do really well here.
cons:
From my personal experience,  relative to the work you do the comp isn't high despite common sentiment about this company. 
Depending on the group you're in things get political, hard to advance your carer if you don't know the right people. 
If you want to move up in the ladder, you have to forget about your personal life and ensure that you work nights and weekends. Plus you need to ensure that the upper management is aware your personal sacrifices.

pros: Good company culture. Goldman Sachs across the globe is considered as one office and hence it makes working in their Bangalore office a real pleasure. Work is what you make of it. There are good opportunities to learn and excel for the right candidate. there is some amount of production support - but then there is motivation to build better systems so the support is reduced
cons: long but consistent working hours. very agile and aggressive environment. one has to give yourself enough time to start feeling comfortable and you need to have high mental strenght to survive and do well in this environment

review_title: The Original Fintech Startup Powerhouse still delivers
pros:
- Best interview process of my life in a context where experience trumped nonsense tech screens.  Sessions involved strategic and domain specific discussions with VP and MD technology leaders and one or two on-the-fly high level technical questions.  Mostly, it felt like a flattering sales pitch.  One of the only times in all my years working that I've left an interview actually feeling good about myself.

- Premium offer over my then base salary, including discussion of expected year end cash awards.  All arrived exactly as conveyed resulting in highest comp received in my 10 professional career

- Moving towards a "startup-lite" culture with business casual attire, working remotely, flexible work hours, social/networking events

- My resume was already decent but adding GS to it brought a torrent of invitations to interview, networking requests and other professional and personal benefits that come with being associated with the top global investment bank.  

- Management structure is flat, with no single person making decisions in solitude, including your direct manager.  A strong network greatly affects project outcomes

- Policy allowing mobility at any time is a big benefit for productive and effective employees as it shifts bargaining power in their favor by forcing managers to keep the situation equitable or find someone else.

- Lots of very brilliant people have worked and/or still remain there from a fairly diverse set of backgrounds.  Literal rocket scientists and multi-PhD superstars all over the place - even as consultants.
cons:
- Strange culture where people often act like doing their job is a favor.  Tricky communicating effectively with intelligent but often thin skinned and/or insecure personality types holding long term senior positions

- Work often comes informally as high level projects along the lines of "rethink and simplify the current expensive but proven solution with delivery of an entirely novel, unproven, theoretically more efficient paradigm" - and then judged somewhat qualitatively on minor points and preferences, shaped by popular opinion.  Politics here are as weird as they are dicey as they are crucial to getting ahead or staying afloat.

- Compensation per employee is nothing like the press/media math of "X profit / Y employees".  It's higher than average in general but there's many who are paid less than their value along with many medium term consultants with no skin in the game.  On the positive side, there's almost no one who adds little to no value and sticks around for more than 3-6 months like all other banks

- Management structure may be flat but largely because of its opaque, convoluted and constantly shifting nature.  This can make it feel like a full political campaign cycle just to screw in a light bulb.

- As crazy as it sounds, if you reach a senior level, it becomes difficult to pursue opportunities outside GS as the universe of companies that can and will provide both a better career trajectory and higher compensation shrinks dramatically.  Those that can can usually have outlandish expectations with only incremental compensation improvement offered - like describing how to build a profitable algorithmic trading system in explicit, low level technical detail over the phone in 10 minutes.

review_title: Good company but too many greedy highly overpaid partners.
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits. Some very smart folks.
cons: Long hours. The pay is good but if if take into consideration the amount of hours you put in (Typical 60-70) its not necessarily all that good. The partners love to take millions in dollars instead of distributing it the folks that truly make this company tick.

review_title: Not as great as it’s hyped up to be, but still decent
job_title: Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Looks great on your resume, decent benefits/perks, love the sense of belonging to the global goldman network

Lots of very smart people to work with and interesting projects to work on

Good flexibility options
cons:
Very long working days (10 hour minimum), salary not as good as it could be given the higher time commitment.

Every team is understaffed. Work day is super intense, no time for a breather (no lunch break!!)

Need to play the politics in order to get promoted. Hard work alone is insufficient.

pros:
Nice suburb office, gym.

Learning experience dealing with people, low quality service from dependent teams, fighting fires caused by poor execution.
cons:
Leadership, managers making people decisions. They hired lots of costly and underperforming contract workers, while allowing underpaid full time employees be responsible for cleaning up the mess and working long hours. High performing employees are not rewarded at this location. There is no incentive that can justify going the extra mile. Management is far more keen on justifying the low cost, high value nature of this location, to a point that the value of marginal out performance is compressed to zero.

Quality of support you receive from the federated teams are dismal and frustrating.

review_title: Be Prepared to Outpace your Compensation
job_title: Talent Advisor in New York, NY
pros: Great place to learn, you can get experience doing very complex things here early on, great place to learn and grow.
cons: Compensation does not move with your title, so if you are very good at your job, you're going to get promoted fast and they're still going to pay you at an entry level or mid level. You will also wind up doing more than one job, and you will get paid below your market value after your first 3 years.

review_title: Fantastic job for beginning a career in finance
pros: Excellent place to work if you're willing to pay the price with your lifestyle and work extremely hard. Definitely a firm that will open doors to other careers in finance and many opportunities for internal advancement if you do a good job.
cons: It's a very competitive firm and you work extremely, extremely hard and that may be a detractor for many people. Not a firm where you can just rest on your laurels. You will sweat every step of the way.

review_title: Great brand name, they make you earn it though
pros: if you stick around long enough you can make crazy money.  The brand name of the company is extremely strong, so you can use it to get future jobs without much issue.
cons: you probably won't want (or be able to) stick around long enough to make crazy money.  Most people don't last 3 years.  It's not that they are all being fired (although some years that might be true), its just an incredibly draining place to work.

review_title: Great place to work with and learn from some of the smartest people in the business.
pros:
1. Working with smart, motivated colleagues - always something new to learn.
2. Exposure to high level clients - both in terms of the specific organizations and the individuals.
3. Compensated well.
cons:
1. Politics, politics, politics - it drives you nuts after a while.  I've seen a number of people leave just for this reason.
2. Hard to get promoted past VP - a lot of it goes back to point 1.
3. Can be difficult to maintain work life balance.

review_title: You Get to Work With the Best
job_title: Operations Analyst in Jersey City, NJ
pros: The facilities and the people that you work with are top notch. You are given a lot of responsibility early on, and if you stick around long enough you'll get promoted at least to the Associate level (pretty much the equivalent of a VP at any other bank).
cons: No work life balance, the work can become really mundane and finding a reason to stick around becomes difficult. Pay can also be better, but because the Goldman name is worth so much on a CV they pay the younger employees less compared to the competitor

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Top notch talent across all levels but the analyst classes began to weaken towards the end of my tenure. Working groups actually accomplished stated goals. Collaborative environment that encouraged everyone (even junior employees) to contribute to discussions and brain storming sessions. Much of the ego driven commentary is overblown but still creeps in from time to time. Management dedication to career development is unparalleled.
cons: Comp has declined - middle managers (VP) get hit hardest in tough years. Cost cutting mindset has taken over where every expense is scrutinized. Shifting blame is the priority and you'll hear "not my problem" much more frequently than in years past.

review_title: Great company to start out a career
pros: Good benefits, salary and bonus, plenty of mentorship opportunities, opportunity for upward mobility. Very good place to start right out of college.
cons: Office politics, definitely more of an "old school" approach to doing business, not focused enough on building out technology, we still use systems and websites built in 2002 to do business

review_title: Don't focus on just the brand.  The role and the team matters alot
pros:
Competitive compensation package
Good growth opportunity in a challenging environment
Working with interesting, intelligent individuals
cons: Like any firm, it really depends on the team, the role, and your personal aspirations.  Contrary to some of the pros mentioned, there are roles and teams that are frustrating to work in and with.  Sometimes, you feel like a dispensable clog that keeps the engine rolling along.

job_title: IT Summer Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- Worked with very smart people
