job_title: Software Developer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
- The benefits package is excellent. You can even get reimbursed for fitness expenses (gym membership, etc.) since they don't have a fitness center on site.
- You get to work with some very smart, motivated people. In spite of what I say in the "cons" section, I liked most of the people I worked with.
cons:
- Everyone works overtime every week. See below for more details.
- Goldman Sachs will own you. Whatever Goldman Sachs asks of you, it will never be too much. I find it interesting that no one complained out loud; taking abuse without complaint was part of the culture.
- Technologies used are very old. Updating them won't happen anytime soon. 
- The firm has very little interest in increasing developers' technology/programming skills. You will sometimes feel more like a business analyst than a programmer.
- Developers have to spend a ridiculous amount of time in meetings. Most of these you will call into, since most attendees will be in other locations. Much of the time you will have nothing to say and will learn nothing from the meetings.
- Email volume is huge. I spent tons of time reading emails (not just automated alerts, etc. but actual emails written by humans).
- Most development teams are split geographically, often with some team members in India. Projects are often divided among developers in India and the U.S., and it's easy to imagine how that would be counterproductive. You only get an hour or two of overlap first thing in the morning where you can discuss project issues with India. Sometimes those India team members call you when they arrive in the morning, India time, for updates - this means late at night calls for you.
- Everyone is expected to be in the office by 7:00 am or 7:30 at the latest, and those arriving late are sometimes told off.
- Just because you arrive at work early every day, don't expect to leave early. Quitting time is 4:30 or 5:00, and that's if you're not working late.
- Every project, every email, every issue is SUPER urgent. This means developers are constantly being pressured to get software released, and routinely need to stay late in order to get things done. The quality of the software suffers as a result.
- When there is a software release, a developer from each team (whether his team is releasing anything or not) has to stay in the office until the release is done and they can verify their teams' software is working correctly. This can be until after 9:00 pm. And don't think you can come in late that morning; you will probably still be expected to arrive at 7:00 am.
- The global nature of the firm makes worldwide meetings a pain for Salt Lake folks. These meetings are sometimes scheduled at 6:00 or 6:30 am, and you will be required to attend.
- Evening and weekend work is a regular thing for many teams. If you are asked to work on a holiday, it's likely you won't get a comp day to make up for it.
- Frequent after-hours phone calls from Production Control for a variety of reasons (nearly always false alarms) - you get these calls regardless of whether you are actually on call.
- Work is not very interesting. The way things work at Goldman, even very small software enhancements can require lots of coordination between many teams, and months' worth of work.
- Most teams' software is mainly written in stored procedures, not Java or some other "real" programming language.
- What Java code they do have is badly written. I think this is partly because the developers are used to writing stored procedures.
- Everyone bows down and worships higher-level management when they come visit. I always found this funny. Once we were asked to clean up our desk areas in anticipation of somebody's visit.
- Work environment is really bad. Lots of people crammed into very large rooms.
- You can't check your personal email at work. This is due to SEC regulations, I believe, but it's a pain.
- There is a lot of big talk about bonuses during the interview process, but for me and others I talked to, we were unimpressed by our bonuses.
- Everything requires lots of approvals. Sometimes things get delayed because management didn't bother to approve.

pros: Working in a highly professional environment with talented prople from all over the world. Very quick, flexible and professional daily work with new challenges permanently provided. Teamwork and information sharing works wery well.
cons: Demanding job with hoge workloads and high level of professionality and immediate completion of tasks and response expected permanently. Hardly any quiet times at work, hard to focus on private affairs during work, or meeting private appontments after work.

job_title: Senior Analyst Developer in New York, NY
pros: Smart people, driven workplace and great benefits.  Goldman truly breads a great culture that you will be proud to say you work for.  Everyone is exceptionally professional.
cons: Very process driven, you often learn processes and procedures unique to Goldman which mitigates the learning of general purpose skills.  You also often feel bogged down by these procedures, requiring you to stay normal working hours to get your real work done.  The result is that Goldman has very poor work-life balance.

job_title: Technology Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Diverse organization. Challenging. Decent benefits.
cons: Extremely bureaucratic. Even a small change or enhancement requires multiple levels of approval and confirmation. Small mistakes are counted against you during appraisals which can be frustrating. Noisy environment - especially working near trading desk - No privacy. Most of them have lunch at their desks - difficult for a fresh graduate to move up the ladder. Maximum number of years that a fresh graduate can survive is not more than 3 years unless he/she has good connections. Continuous change in managers and team - every 6 months. Internal mobility is purely based on performance. Legacy technologies - feels like you are in the mainframe era.

pros: Goldman does a great job of finding smart, talented, driven people. The open culture makes it so that you can speak to people at all different levels--vice presidents, managing directors, etc--and your opinion is given considerable weight, no matter your title.
cons: Very long working hours and zero career development in the operations division. Great people leave the firm because they become frustrated by the lack of professional development.

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great job, amazing and talented coworkers. I am pushed to my fullest potential every day. I spend a lot of time with my managing director, which helps to give direction to my career.
cons: Long hours; I work 60+ hours. If you are someone who does not like intense jobs, then this is not for you. There really are not many negatives.

job_title: Technology Analyst in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
Been working here over a year now.

* Work with great, smart people who are dedicated to their jobs.

* Hours not as bad as one would imagine. You will have the occasional late night dealing with problems in production, or ensuring a deadline for development is met.

* Benefits are absolutely phenomenal (firm pays life insurance, short term disability, has good/great 401k options, provides health, vision, and dental and customizations to plans to fit your specific situation / budgeting, and much much more).

* Compensation is great but not the top -- this probably has to do with a trade off for getting those magical words "Goldman Sachs" on your resume -- there is a large supply for relatively few positions, so they can afford to pay less than some competitors at the lower levels.

* As it turns out the vaunted meritocracy of GS does indeed exist, and the top performers are regularly singled out and given plaudits and earmarked for promotion and better bonuses.

* There's always something interesting going on, whether it's training sessions by industry leaders (like an engineer lead from Google talking about Angular 2), networking events, or talks@GS from famous people (Shaq, Laura Bush, Game of Thrones show runners, etc)
cons:
* In the tech division, at least, there is an ongoing problem where the firm's standards for software keep on changing, resulting in a "hitting a moving target" problem -- by the time you finish upgrading to 2016's software specs, 2017 is here and you have a whole new spec to meet.

* Some of the software specs are great and absolutely worth onboarding to, but some others are head scratchers that provide zero utility and only impede the regular course of software development (looking at you, forms engine).

* While GS is definitely pivoting more and more into technology, resources (and by that I mean people) are still tight. Either the scale of changes should be reined in or more resources should be hired.

job_title: Operations Technical Specialist in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Fair working environment - not leading edge.
cons: Goldman is a very strange mixture of people.  Some people are very smart, people who make very big contribution both inside and outside the company.  However, at least in technology where most of my experience is, there are a number of people who are either completely un-motivated or just not smart at all.  I'd like to refrain from saying they are dumb because that would probably be off the mark, but I have seen a much higher number of people who don't know what they are doing.The corporate culture, as I see it, is very arrogant.  I've found about a 50/50 split between people who are very full of themselves and people who are normal, decent people.

pros: Decent compensation and bonus. Nice facilities.
cons: Little to no room for innovation or a new way of looking at things. I feel bad for the college hires who are a product of their environment and don't know any better way to do things.Those who came up management ranks are well enough off to pay lip service, but don't address any core problems. Some divisions are 10 years or more behind across the board in technology.

review_title: Started off great but working here didn't live up to the reputation or the hype
job_title: Senior Analyst Developer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great opportunity to learn about the financial industry. Worked with incredibly smart people.
cons: Lip service was given to teamwork but senior management seems to give themselves all the credit for success. Sr management makes promises but keep their word to their employees. Mentors and advocates are needed for lateral hires but mentors are the only ones they help with

pros: Name, reputation, some smart people
cons: political, toxic, hyper competitive, not positive "work and challenge" stress but a lot of negative stress from people and politics. Environment is not a place that allows open discussion and people can positively challenge view points. Many people are not open minded.

job_title: Tax Operations in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Fast paced - put in a lot of hours for the salary and benefits.
cons: They never tell you everything, you will never be good enough, and most not in the top quartile work out of fear of losing their job.  Of course they don't tell you which quartile you are in.  You are watched the entire time you are in the building.  No privacy.

review_title: Honest review for my 2.5 years journey in Goldman Sachs
pros:
1. Office campus is neat and well established
2. Unlimited sick days
3. Flexible timings for tech folks.
4. Free medical facilities for basic health queries. 
That's all. Couldn't think of anything else.
cons:
1. Good work is done mainly in platforms team. Rest everyone is working on proprietary tools made by platforms team. 
3. Too much workload. 
4. Only 20% team have good work.
5. Their thumb rule: Hire people by giving them very high package and then eventually dissolve them with others in yearly appraisals unless you are in boss's good books. 
6. Very costly food and gym.
7. Usual politics like other organisation.

review_title: Marcus - rapidly becoming the call center job you didn’t sign up for.
pros:
• The benefits are top notch, much more available to employees beyond the traditional health/vision/dental.  The 401K plan is extremely generous for employees after their first anniversary, and tuition reimbursement is available at $10k a year.

• Learning opportunities - you will learn more than you can possibly imagine.  The networking that comes from the groups, events, and cross-division/departmental projects really help expand your skill set and resume.

• Resume booster- a large percentage of my colleagues came to the firm for this very reason.  Post Goldman life has also been very nice for most as they move on to other opportunities.

• People - It was a privilege to work with such a talented group of people.  Everyone has great ideas, strengths, and works extremely hard.  

Also of note, there are a lot of opportunities available to volunteer locally, people do really seem to genuinely care about what they do, and I was extremely impressed with how the firm handled any HR type issues.
cons:
• Work/Life balance.  I was fortunate to work in a division that offered overtime, however extra hours were always available and it was strongly encouraged to work extra.

• Stress- Do more with less seems to be the philosophy here.  Departments seem to be understaffed, overworked, and undertrained.  Management seems to be reactive to change in staffing rather than proactively working to make the day easier for employees.  Turnover is extremely high for a company of this caliber in the division I was in.

• Pay - pay is subpar, and employees are discouraged from discussing this with each other.  Annual raises, bonuses, and promotional increases could use some work to be in the same league as other companies.

• Internal promotion can be difficult depending on the needs of your team.  The firm tends to hire outside, and tends to promote management more frequently than those that work in operations.  There’s not a lot of transparency about career pathing, and that heavily impacts morale.

review_title: Great people in the organization, management culture not so much
job_title: Vice President Operations in Dallas, TX
pros: Working with some of the smartest and driven people around. Your cohorts help you evlevate your performance and are very creative. There is great overall collaboration and independence given.
cons: Management needs to adapt to the times. Although the firm and the new CEO want to focus more on culture development and fairness, the MD's and Sr VPs who have been with the firm for quite some time still treat it like an old boys club. There is clear and sometimes unfair preference given to "freinds" of the Sr VPs and MDs when it comes to promotions and bonuses.

review_title: The people and environment are the best reason to work here.
job_title: Senior Software Developer in New York, NY
pros:
The people and the environment are the best reasons to work at Goldman Sachs.  Everyone is committed to helping one another, no matter how busy they are.  
It's very much a meritocracy; if you do well, they will give you more responsibility so that  you will always feel challenged.
cons: It's not an environment for superstars if that is what you like.  All important decisions are very much group based decisions and the culture is very team oriented.  You are graded on how well you perform in a team because it's very important.

review_title: Co workers are smart and hardworking.  You will be compensated.  However, don't expect much of a life outside of work
job_title: Investment Banking Associate in New York, NY
pros: In the medium to long run, it's a very meritocratic firm to work for.  People work hard, and are recognized for their efforts.
cons: As you get more senior, there is more 'politicking' particularly since so much of comp is bonus based.  Baseline is you do a great job with excellent performance.  Then you need to network on top to get paid.

review_title: They work you hard. It wont pay off unless you stick around for a while.
job_title: Operations Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: High stress work environment can be invigorating but can also turn you into a grouch. A mixture of highly motivated, intelligent people with the terminally mean, stuck-in-this-job-for-life crowd. A lot of turnover--many people leave for better paying, less stressful firms who don't have as impressive sounding name.
cons: Work becomes your life and has to be your number one priority to be successful at GS.  Salaries in Salt Lake office are surprisingly low, don't count on much of a bonus, or overtime pay either. You'll be monitored every second of every day.

review_title: Exceptional, highly-stressed and competitive people struggling to like their jobs and each other in a global sweatshop.
pros: People are exceptional, resources are stellar, compensation is good, prestige is high, hierarchy is complex: feels very flat in day-to-day activities (see cons), great diversity.
cons: Hours are long, stress is HIGH, turnover is high, work can be dull, hierarchy: there's an "us vs. them" aspect to partners vs. the rest of the field, networking is mandatory and thus becomes mechanical and insincere.

pros:
1. Good salary package
2. Market leaders in Investment banking
3. You get to learn a lot from the senior leadership
cons:
1. If you are a hard core techie then this is not the place to be. They use oldest of the old technologies and you cannot even suggest a new technology to be used as the company is not biased towards it.
2. You will not grow as a technologist in this company. 
3. The company thrives on politics. A lot of good talent was allowed to go away as they did not suck up to their bosses

job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits including medical dental vision etc, smart people, professional environment, decent pay. Management is generally well informed, involved in day to day operations.
cons: You will work a lot of hours. 50 hours is the expected minimum, with some people working 70 plus. Upper management and mid level often have different ideas of changes that are needed.

job_title: Investment Banking Associate in London, England
pros: Great brand. Huge network. Decent location in London. Great source of research and information.
cons: Nepotism (and consequently the effects of entitlement) run rampant. No guidance so it's definitely sink or swim. Must have network to survive from Day1 so strive to build one before joining, which is hard. Review system is flawed - you can pick who reviews you and if someone doesn't pick you back it's never questioned even if they end up giving you a bad review (pure trickery)

pros: Most of my co-workers are great, bright people. Overall the structure of the company is flat, which means you can reach out and speak to people from any level (up to a partner). The working hours are flexible and they respect personal arrangements.
cons: The company could benefit from employing a 20% (fun-time) rule, similar to Google. I think many employees have good ideas for side projects which often get overshadowed by day-to-day priorities.

review_title: Fun internship, declined full time offer
pros:
The name on your resume opens doors
Fun intern activities!
Salt Lake City isn't as expensive as the New York/NJ Office area
cons:
Pay is incredibly low as compared to the front-end of the company (Investment Banking, etc...)
Stern hierarchy where you CANNOT talk to certain people or else it is frowned upon because... well, who do you think YOU are?
Their HR (aka HCM) is very unorganized
No one actually talks about what they think of the firm. If you ask, usually you get, "Oh it's fantastic!" then you hear the person quit a few months later...

pros: Very intelligent and motivated people. Work assignments are high profile and interesting. Leading the way in trying to make the job more manageable for juniors (Saturday exception etc.). Good deal flow across teams and offices.
cons: Hours can be challenging, despite recent efforts to improve work life balance. Stress levels can be high at times, and analyst and associates are expected to learn quickly and to constantly take on increasing levels of responsibility.

review_title: Goldman Sachs earns much too much due to its privileged position
pros:
- you will get high salary
- you will see how big banks take advantage of their privileged position in the financial markets
cons:
- very bureaucratic organization; quite often the internal systems do not work, people in remote locations are usually not helpful, processes are sometimes conflicting and illogical; you may end up running in circles without any progress
- it seems quite often that superiors care about only themselves and do not help their reports do their jobs
- a lot of management gobbledygook; I guess, they earn a lot and have to pretend that they are worth it

pros:
An environment centered around diversity of thought.
A myriad of opportunities to step outside your comfort zone to elicit growth and development.
A true meritocracy
This was an experience that has shaped all subsequent opportunities in a profoundly positive way by helping me cultivate skill sets I was unaware I possess and challenging my patterns of thought.
cons: The same intensity that drove my positive experience can be a double edge sword.  I found it easy to spread oneself too thin.

review_title: Smart, driven people, but terrible work-life balance
job_title: Equity Research Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Goldman's reputation enables it to hire some of the smartest and most talented individuals I've ever worked with.
cons: The culture places a huge emphasis on face-time. If you're willing to stay the longest in the office, and produce the most output,  you'll likely be a top-bucket analyst. This mentality is embedded in the culture.

pros:
- Great place to start your career right out of school
- Awesome co -workers that are always willing to help and teach
- Compensation is on the rise. 2018 brought bumps in pay for FAs
- Technology across the firm is being overhauled(new computers, servers and business applications)
- Goldman is leaning in to give Ayco more support and becoming more involved in growing the firm.
cons: - Still a decent amount of work left to be done

review_title: Great pay, interesting work, culture is meh
pros: Super interesting work, very entrepreneurial (lots of room to pursue projects you find interesting, senior management are good, focus on junior folks getting opportunities to learn (came to GS with zero finance experience and team were excellent at getting me up to speed), excellent pay
cons: Middle management layer (VPs) have a lot of autonomy and as a junior you work very closely with them. Often they are trying to make MD and so present juniors with unrealistic demands / do not let them present any of the work they produce.

review_title: Quality of people cannot be matched
job_title: Business Analyst in New York, NY
pros: There is a great environment of meritocracy where everyone collaborates extensively. The caliber of people that work at Goldman is second to none. There is a noticeable difference in how efficiently things get done here compared to other firms. By being a part of the firm, you get a true understanding of why we are repeatedly the best on the Street. There are so many intangibles that set us apart and being a part of that is truly rewarding.
cons: Longer hours is always a drawback but is to be expected in this industry.

job_title: Technology Analyst in Jersey City, NJ
pros: You have a great management team which will help you at every stage of your career. The feedback given by the your immediate manager and your peers will be immediate and honest. They also have a great year-end review system. They take great care of ensuring career progression.
cons: Goldman Sachs is known for long working hours. There is also too much pressure if you don't "fit" in their culture. The pay is abysmal for people starting out with most of it being shared by the upper management. Though they try to evaluate your performance objectively, lot of things depend on perception.

pros:
In most of the departments, work with one the best team in the industry. One can learn and grow very quickly.
Compensation is the highest in the industry, provided you work for revenue-generating divisions (Equities, FICC, IBD or Merchant Banking).
The much publicized focus on team work is indeed very true. It does not only apply on your local coworkers, but also globally with other teams in other locations working in the same area. From my experience, other firms are a lot more fragmented.
cons: Probably the long hours, but that is a common theme in the financial industry.

job_title: Vice President Technology in New York, NY
pros: Phenomenal team work & razor sharp focus on achieving deliverables. Great compensation
cons: For a technology focussed professional its a big let down, very low to primitive  on technology standards, haphazard work environment with zero SDLC adoption, SQL focussed shop with very poor java/middlware skills amongst employees. Most technology employees have extremely limited skill sets on enterprise java or C# and as a result gravitate towards SQL based solutions for any type of problems. This may be a big let down for prospective employees looking for exciting work in enterprise middle-ware space.

pros: It's one of the globally known securities firms, which makes me proud of working for GS. I don't know if I want to keep working here but this is a good opportunity to brush up my skills
cons: Great people, great atmosphere. and the best thing to work at GS is that I can get great access to people who are thought to be global leaders in decades.

review_title: terrific, but low salary for the kind of work they extract
pros: excellent people to work with, friendly and helpful atmosphere, good career prospects, global teams, great work load, intense working environment
cons: work load can get to you at times, and when the salary is not that good, it can be frustating. The same analysts in NY get almost 5 times more than what we get in India.

review_title: Great place to start with significant opportunity for growth depending on performance
job_title: Credit Risk Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The company has great benefits and a strong culture of unity and hard work.  My position is highly analytical, but you might not get that as an operations employee.  Your duties will depend completely on what teams are available when you start if you are in the operations division.
cons: The culture and tasks of the individual team you are placed on in Salt Lake will determine more about your overall experience than anything else.

review_title: It used to be a great place to work
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: There are still some great people at GS who embody the old culture and values of teamwork and making decisions based on what's right for the project vs. what actions will lead to a faster promotion.
cons: The culture has shifted to one where only self-serving people are in positions of power, making short-term personal greedy rewarded and the norm.

pros: It's a great place to work. I made a lot of friends there. But one thing I would advise for anyone looking into a career within the firm is that you have to have a thick skin, so be prepared to take a lot from people because at times it can be an incredibly unforgiving place.
cons: Very bureacratic at times. Also they work you incredibly hard there so if you don't like hard work Goldman is not the place for you. For me personally, I have had to sacrifice a lot of my friendships and hardly see them due to always being at work.

review_title: Very competitive environment providing plenty of opportunities for shaking up one's career every couple of years.
job_title: Client Relationship Manager in London, England
pros: One of the top Asset Managers around. Big enough to give its best people lots of opportunity to take side steps, to step up or to move to another country. Being part of Goldman has also sit perks such as having access to an impressive intellectual capital.
cons: There is no respite and far too much politics. In order to succeed you not only need to be good. You need to be better than your peers.

pros: "You think" you are being paid high.. "you think" you are with intelligent people..
cons:
Dirtiest place to work, People here are very politically charged... They looks like experts in their field but they are cunning enough to showcase themselves like experts.
I have been working here since last 8 years, (one would wonder it takes me 8 years to understand but I have been changing departments and everywhere its same).. believe me this place actually suck blood from talented people and reward to cajolers. Even if you think you can downgrade yourself to please your manager there will be somebody who can beat you in doing this.
You can waste important years of your life by joining this firm.

pros:
-firm reputation looks great on your resume
-intelligent staff
-nice working conditions
-good internal mobility for those who make the effort
cons:
-always worried about being fired
-not a very friendly atmosphere( I understand you are there to work but jeech people! )
-sad to senior peers let go/fired
-high turnover rate( Jeez I wonder why )

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Smart people; Strong technology organization; Plenty of learning opportunities; Great place to start your career out of school due to strong intern and new analyst programs; looks great on your resume
cons: very political; not enough to just be good at your job - you need someone senior to push your career forward; technology organization is undergoing a radical change - not necessarily for the better;  compensation model deteriorated

pros: The people are fantastic; motivated, outgoing, and intelligent.
cons: They treat contingent workers badly. Terrible hourly wage, 60 hours a week routinely, dull backoffice work, with little respect or mobility given to people in contingent positions. To give perspective, I left the FX ICON team to become VP of machine learning at a competitive firm, so experience or competency was not an issue.They are genuinely treated poorly.

pros: Probably stating the obvious, but the pay is great. I also really like the people I work with, which makes the hours easier. Supervisors take an interest in you, and the other analysts have become some of my best friends.
cons: Hours are long. Especially coming in at the intro level, you have to be prepared to give them everything you have. Competitive atmosphere might be a con for some. I really like the people I work with, but it's not exactly a diverse group—I can imagine that someone that doesn't "fit the mold" wouldn't feel the same way.

pros: Good parking. A few good managers. Great community outreach projects. The CEO is a wonderful man, very approachable.
cons: Where to begin? If you complain about a co-worker (or God forbid, a manager), you are usually written up then marked as a trouble maker. Favoritism and nepotism runs rampant in all departments. The ops department is lead by incompetence and bias. PTO is given, but employees are frowned upon when they take time off. Computer systems are dated and slow. Ayco is basically GS's red headed step child, and it's affiliation with GS only goes as far as the name. Raises and bonuses are a joke, equal to 1% of gross pay for admin staff, when management are rewarded with thousands. Overall, a really bad place to work.

pros:
Ideal place for a person who likes fast pace.
Great leadership and they help you groom yourself as a leader
You get to learn a lot about financial markets. They do a great job of inviting the leaders from many streams to learn from their perspectives.
cons:
Difficult to work flexible hours / WFH at a firm like GS. In person and on time matters a lot.
As the firm got significantly larger you feel a bit lost in the org structure which is not very transparent.
Compensation varies significantly with market swings - so not ideal for a person seeking stability.

review_title: You're paid well but be ready for long hours. Also, experience highly varies from team to team.
pros: This is highly dependent on the team you land on.  GS is a big place and I don't think any single pro/con list is going to fairly represent _anything_.  On the team I worked on though:  We were paid well, the work was engaging, and we had great clients who gave us requirements and used our products.  For the US-side, absolutely fantastic people.  Smart, good work-ethics, great stuff.  Challenging work, good access to managers, and we had a great MD too.
cons:
This is highly dependent on the team you land on.  GS is a big place and I don't think any single pro/con list is going to fairly represent _anything_.  On the team I worked on, the support structure was a mess.  We were paid well but were called on weekends when our support rotation came up (and in the beginning years, there weren't support rotations, it was just all hands on deck when crises happened).  Code upkeep and (non-existent) documentation: A complete mess. God help whatever people inherits our code.  Also, there were emergency calls in the middle of the night (rare, but it happened) and our off-shore team didn't work well with our US-side team.

For the record: Our US-team was only about five people though.  A small team.

Finally: Our technical process was a mess.  People simply wrote code and committed.  No process whatsoever for deployments.  Inconsistent dev/qa/prod environments.  No build/packaging pipeline.  No easy way to revert code base.  Loose-class deployments by manually breaking apart jars.  You get the idea.

review_title: Stay away if you love programming
pros:
a)People assume you are very rich because you work at GS.
b)You meet some very capable individuals
cons:
a) Despite the constant sound of GS being "one team", the differences even in terms of facilities such as the kind of desk, floor and coffee machines between Technology and Operations are significant with Technology being treated like a doormat.
b) Despite the recent attempts at calling themselves a "Technology Company competing with Google for talent", the fact is neither the pay nor the average quality of engineers is even 20% of what Google is.
c) While there is gym and cafeteria, it is cheaper to walk outside the building and find a better food/facility at half the price you pay within the building.
d) Toxic politics with constant bickering amongst middle management who see no chance of moving to MD level and are always frustrated
e) While the company boasts about teamwork, you are alone when there is a crisis due to some inadvertent mistake. You will be punished severely with multiple people questioning you why you went wrong 0.01% while nobody appreciates when you were right 99.99%
f) Company doesn't believe in spending even a single dime on you besides your compensation signed in the offer letter. You will be asked to attend many Friday evening drinks all of which are self-funded and you pay around 20 bucks even if you just had a 3 dollar beer.
g) You will not learn any new technical skills
h) Nobody will allow you to work on a new open source technology unless the bureaucracy has approved it. That means hundreds of people spend loads of time doing the same repetitive work in Excel.
i) Too much time wasted on useless meetings with incapable people.
j) Work from home is not encouraged. 
k) Work space is extremely congested for Technology team with everyone sitting next to each other with a gap of less than 1 feet on a large open bench.

pros: Awesome people great office to work
cons: Sometimes it’s really cold in conference rooms

pros:
-Goldman Sachs Name
-If you are in an analyst/planner role, you learn a lot about the financial planning process
-Family culture
-Casual environment (golf shirts, casual Fridays, no ties, cardigans, and colorful attire)
cons:
-If you are hired as an admin professional, you are essentially “doomed” to that position. There are no crossovers into analyst positions, no matter your educational background and work ethic. If you do happen to have a Bachelor’s degree and desire a path in this industry, get hired as an analyst from the start. Very defined divisions between admin, analyst, and advisor. The analysts and advisors look down on admins and act like they're uneducated, but many of them do have college degrees.
-Slow progress. You’re an analyst for like 7-10 years and then all of a sudden you’re an “account manager” aka financial advisor and making $100k+. 
-Cyclical work. It’s the same work all the time: meeting preps and tax returns. Why do we even do tax returns? 
-The expectation that you have to stay late to appear productive. For all mgmt knows, you could be googling at your computer, but it “looks good.”
-Old school systems
-No supplemental compensation system for admins and analysts (other firms do this!)

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: There are no slackers here, they just don't last. It can be a very rewarding place to work, with so many smart people. Everyone pulls in the same direction and it's a very collective environment.
cons: The forced quartiling of staff is frankly 1980s MBA strategy and needs to end. While the firm is committed to diversity there is a lot more to be achieved in this space. The firm is incredibly hard charging and over the long run that can get challenging, particularly when children and partners enter lives.

job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: This firm has a wealth of talented people (although you might not get to interact with them depending on your role). Many people here find it a prestige to work at GS.
cons:
Limited opportunities to move across business functions and inter-departments. 
Lack of communication from management of what's going on within the firm and in the financial markets.
Whether you'll find the firm a great place to work also depends a great deal on the people you work with. It could be fun and rewarding with the right people but stressful and unproductive with arrogant, self-righteous co-workers and managers.

job_title: Senior Analyst Developer in New York, NY
pros: Sr. Mgmt makes a lot of effort of retaining staff in the firm. Good benefits
cons: The firm lacks uniformity. IT staff gets a second class citizen treatment and causes a lot of IT folks to get demotivated.  IT bonuses are miniscule compared to the business side.

pros: great teamwork as others have mentioned. . almost a lockstep sense of promotion and benefits since (most) everyone is highly qualified. prob most meritocratic firm on the st, looks solid on the resume for post-gs opportunities.
cons: "culture" is a bit ambiguous - mostly how much work can you handle? long hours, but that is true of all firms. mostly you either cut it, or you don't, and unless you are a superstar, this is mostly by "feel" or fit.

pros: Very intelligent hardworking people surrounding you. Opportunities for professional challenges abound. Quick learning curve and never a dull day. Technical courses provide a great chance to learn from the professionals
cons: Far too much focus on workplace politics and senior management exposure. Middle managers will run you into the ground and try to take credit for your work. Hard work and good ideas are not as valued if they are not in line with the managers goals.

pros: Having enormous expectations before joining the firm I was still overwhelmed by the level of people I was surrounded at Goldman Sachs. It is truly the best financial services firm out there.
cons: The downside was as expected - long working hours are a part of the investment banking career, and my experience at Goldman was not an exception.

pros: Fairly well compensated (though in line with comparable firms), good benefits, including an onsite gym. Some very good, decent, smart people.
cons: "Kool-aid drinkers" advance; others don't. Little tolerance for constructive suggestions or criticism. Focus on technical process at the expense of cultivating employees. People have been burned out since the 2008 meltdown, with few new hires after several rounds of layoffs.

job_title: Eexcutive Vice President, Human Testing Programs in San Diego, CA
pros: You have freedom and time to be an entrepreneur within the organization. Plus they have a great gym, in-door shooting range with free ammo, fully paid for healthcare and well stocked bar.
cons: They have been lowering the standard a bit on employees. I wish we would be a bit more patience in hiring. We use to hire only the best and brightest – now we hire bright. fact is these days we seem to let anyone in with a pulse and a FB page. The HR staff should be used as a social experiment and replaced – but that is just me.

review_title: Very professional, but nothing is perfect either.
job_title: Computer Specialist in New York, NY
pros:
I had worked at other financial companies such as Tiaa-Cref and Bankers Trust, but Goldman had the best climate.  I had to interact with many upper management folks and never had a bad experience.  
I made the most money for what I did at Goldman.  They pay very well and the bonuses were fantastic.
cons: I did have a few horrible experiences with people from IT, where I worked.  It appeared that integrity and professionalism was directly proportional to how much money you made.

job_title: Voice Engineer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great firm with great benefits.  Work was challenging and team was good to work with.  I enjoyed the time I was there
cons: Upper management is very disconnected with teams.  My team was once referred to as trained monkeys.  Managers were told to not get attached to employees avoid after work interaction.

review_title: Smart people, but trying too hard
pros:
1. Very motivated and smart people surrounding you
2. Most people are fairly collaborative and happy to help / answer questions
3. Get rewarded for performance, very meritocratic place
cons: Culture centers around hard work and 'doing one's time.' There is an obsession with showing how hard one is working, as opposed to being efficient with time and leaving office at a reasonable hour.  I worked with an MD (fairly up the ranks) whose wife had a baby & 2 wks later he was back at work, pulling 3am nights every day of the week. Go home to your wife, man.

review_title: Great company, but in banking industry
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: great people, can-do approach, constant search for new ideas and new ways of doing things, constant pressure to improve, develop, move forward.
cons: Industry that is on the downward slope: politically, reputationally, technically, legally, etc...Regulation will strangle it overtime, money and opportunities to make it will dry up and so will the talent pool working there. Perhaps not for 10 or so years, but Goldman is changing and not for the better overall. Unfortunately.

review_title: Good learning experience but not a place to build a career (S&T)
pros: Work with smart people in a fast paced environment. You learn how to work hard, work smart, and deal with demanding clients. The analyst class training experience and summer internship provides a great network for future endeavors.
cons: Many managers are not focused on talent development and retention. The industry is getting smaller and the firm will continue to cut back. New regulatory strictures will continue to chisel away margins and profits.

job_title: Quantitative Risk Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: 1. Some opportunities to interact with front desks and other teams
cons:
1. Long working hours, and frankly waste of time doing nothing
2. Not much opportunity to learn new knowledge
3. Too much useless automation project that will be easily replaced by other projects from other teams
4. Mandatory lay off during the layoff season. The layoff choice is determined by how the senior management thinks if you do well or not, and not by the actual performance
5. Not much quantitative materials about the role itself but they try to make the role looks fancy
6. Very low pay

review_title: Great place - if you are in the top 25%
pros: Strong work ethic, good people to work with, plenty of opportunities if you are a performer. Strong consensus driven environment, single opinions but forged into teamwork encouraged so all voices can be heard.
cons:
Need to be a performer to get anywhere, constant push to go forwards (or risk becoming an underperformer - there is no choice to "stay where you are").

There are some institutionalised individuals at senior level with closed minds and rigid views.

review_title: The Best People in the Industry
pros: Goldman consistently attracts the best people in finance. It has a tremendous culture of teamwork and communication. The leadership is far-sighted and steers the firm well in tumultuous markets. The platform opens incredible doors all around the world.
cons: The firm has become increasingly commercial over the years, which is obviously the point of the entire enterprise, but in a way that can be off-putting. The overarching mission of the company has become less inspiring. The hours can be brutal.  And compensation is lower than industry average because their brand is at the top of the industry.

pros: The name Goldman Sachs on your resume.
cons: Operations at GS is nothing more than clicking buttons and processing all day for 12 hours a day.  I have seen very intelligent people leave the firm because there simply is nothing rewarding about it. The culture in operations reflects the job. People are constantly stressed out with no work life balance with  far from positive culture.  It is common to hear people joke about "jumping off of a cliff".

review_title: Better then most, but not as good as it seems.
job_title: Vice President Equities  in New York, NY
pros: Firm recognition.  There is a great deal of respect for the Goldman Sachs name outside of the firm.  They offer excellent benefits, and I hear some horror stories from people at other firms.
cons: Just because a person is a senior manager does not mean they are an effective leader; some of the senior level people believe they are better then most of the people working under them,  and I find them not as open to productive arguments as they should.

pros: It's a famouse firm and you will get a mount of opptunities to prove your own value. Working is hard but pleasant, we can learn so many things in our jobs and you will find your life more lively.
cons: Money or health, it's a question. The hard working will make you sleep tight but not easy to get up, especially in winter.

review_title: You are in control of your career
pros:
You are in control of your career - I think the phrase above comes from some HR brochure, but it's largely true at Goldman.  Your promotions (and to a large extent your compensation) are based almost entirely on your performance, not some set schedule or years of experience.  Those who have excellent performance are promoted rapidly and their compensation increases far beyond what an average salary might be in the this field.  Those whose performance is poor or average are asked to leave the firm, so you are always left working with only the best people.

The technology organization is surprisingly agile and people can quickly move between projects as business priorities change.  There is very little tolerance for wasteful work or projects that do not serve a clear business purpose.  There are 3 general job roles people can perform in technology at GS based on their skills and interests, with a focus on business analysis at one and of the spectrum and focus on tech infrastructure at the other end.  Putting people in these roles creates people who are highly skilled experts in a specific area and reduces the number of inefficient "jacks of all trades".
cons: There are some day-to-day politics which reduce the efficiency of the organization, but to a much smaller extent than at other firms.  Some people don't like the amount of work or the long hours, but I feel they might just be working for the wrong firm.

pros:
Very collaborative work culture. Tremendous focus on career growth - in fact improving yourself is not something they help you with - it is something you are _required_ to do otherwise you will be in the "bottom" for consideration when every year 5% of the worst performers are let go.
Work from home is supported where it makes sense.
cons:
Technology hours are not as bad as banking hours, but still on average 10 to 12 hours a day (plus some other emergency every few days)
The company used to be flatter 10 years ago, now there is more middle management.

review_title: Amazing experience - need to do justice to this company
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
*Very knowledgeble, professional, respectful employess and management, very positive environment
*Ability to work from home when necessary and work-place flexibility - a must if you have a family
*Good pay, in line with the market rate for similar roles. However, the media reports about several hundred thousand of compensation per employess are bloated. The numbers are severely skewed by taking into account a few higher-paying executives.
* Tecnologies used are more up to date than in other large financial firms/investment banks (but I'm speaking about my dept only)
*Ability to propose/share your own ideas (to certain extent, since I was a consultant) 
* The company *does* care about its reputation
* I didn't not have any full-time perks as I was a consultant and still, I was very, very  happy with the job. 
* In general, it was a very, very positive experience and I'd love to go back there either as a consultant or full-time if the company starts hiring back
cons: One word: layoffs. There is good communication between management and employees about the possibility of upcoming layoffs, but this is still stressful for everyone, both employees and management. I guess it is stressfull for the company itself since they need to show the investors that they are cutting costs and cannot keep the good employees they would have otherwise have tried to keep.

review_title: Politically adept workforce and leadership with little people management skills despite rhetoric

Organization with deep pockets

Smart people

Recent influx of 'outsiders' a huge contrast to dedicated long-term employees

360 review process is a sham and political tool
Large established organization better at marketing itself than delivering what it promises

review_title: good place to start your career but gets political when you stay longer
job_title: Technical Analyst in Jersey City, NJ

pros: GS is the best of the best at Investment banking. Most of the people are good, decent people. They are ethical and invest a lot in you and make sure you get all of the training you need.

review_title: Great brand, experience out of school
pros: Provides excellent training and career growth, especially at a junior people. Reputation holds its weight in a future job search. New efforts to stress work-life balance and recently adopted higher base pay to new IBD full-time analysts (to lure them away from the tech industry, etc.) are also a plus.
cons: High turnover of excellent individuals. Very hierarchical and high-pressure. Not all middle-level managers are an inspiring bunch.

job_title: Technology Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Very nice work environment, work hours very good, best gym and health services. There are so many perks that you can go to: e.g. free MOMA entry for you + friends
cons: There is no free food in the building. The food rotates every week, but they are a little bit pricy. Although there are discounts on food in certain hours, it is still pricy.

job_title: Technical Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- People are nice and friendly. Throughout ~2 years I've only heard my manager yelled once (at someone else), and he immediately felt bad and apologized. However I've heard different stories on the trading floor since the pace/environment is more stressful there
- I can feel that almost everybody who is successful at GS are very very similar in personality, manner and in their ways of doing things. I think in order to become successful at GS you must become one of those "polished" political figures - great at talking, great at selling yourself, great at doing things that make your managers notice you, great at networking and befriending everybody around you. I just don't think I am a great fit for that but if that's what you want to become, working at GS would help you achieve that really fast.
cons:
- Low salary compared to the rest of the industry. When I was interviewing for other Tech companies (Google, FB) while at GS, after I report my current salary to their the compensation team they all say that this is way below the industry and they will just disregard that while calculating my package. My offer from those two places is more than twice as much as what I am being paid at GS (which is around mid 80s)
- Not much focus in Technology. Can't blame them. You are not driving the revenue. As an application developer I am usually being grouped to the "IT guys" and asked to fix their keyboards. 
- Too much focus on soft skill. When I was at my training, our mentor was some guy who is very smart but a little lacking in manners. He would be wearing rather casual and messy clothes, and usually not very good at saying fancy welcoming words. All my peers however seem to disregard him as "one of the worst mentor ever" "cannot possibly represent GS", although this person possesses really great technical skills and passed me some really great knowledge.
- Technology wise, the place is rather dysfunctional. Many people leave and come so often, so there are always codes lying around not being maintained properly. The project I worked on for a whole year and only have 10 users and no one seems to care. When discussing visions of some potential new projects my team would be launching, manager is always talking about how they can "convince" the business people who decides the annual budgets, while rarely talks about if it would really be helpful to the users.
- In the technology division a lot of senior people are in fact very smart and have strong background. but in the recent years the newer recruits, there are less people who are actually smart and passionate about technology, most of the really talented ones go for somewhere else that pays way more.

pros:
1. Good place to learn.
2. Neat offices and young people around.
3. Growth is fairly decent.
4. Flexible in terms of work from home on ad hoc basis.
5. Mandatory 2 weeks at a stretch annual leave.
cons:
1. Work life balance is absolutely absent.
2. Pay is very decent, not at par with competitors.
3. Lot of team politics, need to be close to manager to get things.
4. Internal mobility is difficult to come by.
5. Open door policy is a sham, people will ask questions on why you stepped into an MD's cabin.

pros: Brand name, money, opportunity to travel internationally, opportunity to experience US-style infrastructure in India, opportunity to come to the office is formal office wear and feel self-important (if it is important in your friends and family to hold a great sounding title and go to office in serious looking clothes), will set you up in posh style for any company related outings or travel
cons:
Work: 
In India, crappy operations roles, hires highly overqualified people just because it can (has the money to bring them over), low end work (project management doesn't need more than 6yrs of work experience), lot of lip service to enabling Indian hires ownership and engagement, truth is all decisions of any value are driven directly from HQ. Work is dead-end, after a few years here you will not be worth anything anywhere else except in exactly similar roles in similar companies

HR:
Follows US style hiring practices, hire & fire at will. Do not lose opportunity to interview elsewhere if it falls into your lap even if you're not looking. This company has no loyalty to you and you will be mistaken to offer the same to it. Company feels it does you a favor to offer a job here. Prides itself in running you through their famous gruelling interview rounds, not uncommon for people to talk to a dozen people before decision. But interviews themselves are mediocre, if you are sharp and speak good English you can get through no problem.

Technology:
Worst place to work in IT. No respect for work, never given resources to do good work. Typically 2 people will do work that Infosys bills 20 people to do. Not saying Infosys is efficient, but you get my drift. 

Culture:
No team culture, no fun events. Company very pushy for you to drink their cool-aid and conform. Company philosophy is - we hire smart aggressive people and they all can rationalize behavior to collaborate or backstab as needed to keep performing for money. Severely restricted internet access - no gmail, no nothing. 

Other cons:
will need to carry 2 phones. People will watch your movements - when you get up from desk, how much time you spend talking with someone etc. Company brings in foreigners (ex-pats) to show how its done. Some expats are great, but there are some who quickly realize 'our' cultural issues viz-a-viz white foreigners and exploit it mercilessly.

pros: Good job opportunities in upstate New York, an area where finance opportunities are rare. Ayco hires lots of young professionals.
cons: Ayco tries to emulate the Goldman culture and expects the same commitment from it's employees, but does not provide any of the financial benefits of actually working for Goldman.

review_title: Goldman Sachs - An Experience for the Better

cons: The hours, but you know what you're signing up for when you're coming in. It's not a 9-5, but it's not a 24/7 job either.

review_title: Best place to start a career

pros: Bonus is the most impressive part also they have good insurance policy and good pay (However not like before), Greatest Brand to be in Resume.

job_title: Associate in Salt Lake City, UT

review_title: This place is not the best place

review_title: Once great place to invest and work now a regulatory thicket and a bad place to be an investor
job_title: Special Situations Group in Hong Kong
pros: Still high quality people across the business, great access to the street as a buy sider in SSG and reasonably competitive comp. The group has an infamously broad mandate across products and liquidity profiles - some corporate bonds here, busted mortgages there, fund a bit of EM infrastructure here and buy some distressed real estate there - that is pretty hard to find anywhere in the market.
cons:
SSG is now a very tough place to invest. Unlike GSPS which was spun out into asset management and a number of funds SSG is still a balance sheet business and thus has to bear the full brunt of the Volcker rule and all the capital changes and regulatory changes to banks. Getting deals and trades done has become extremely difficult. I wouldn't say they pay much less as a % of your profits than a few years ago, its just that there's hundreds of powerpoint slides and multiple layers of approvals to make those profits. It is unequivocally a bad place to be a liquid markets or event driven investor now due to the Volcker rule. Unfortunately SSG makes way too much money (both revenues and operating income) for the bank to give it up as yet hence this limbo of no one being able to leave due to stock vesting schedules and the bank's refusal to allow any mobility outside the group into GSAM.

For prospective employees you should be fully aware SSG is basically Hotel California: 

"You can [mentally] check out any time you like [as a number of Partners have done], 
But you can never leave [with your unvested stock, unless your years at the firm plus your age > 60]!"

cons: Some divisions are better to work for than others.  If you are working for the wrong person, it can be an unsatisfying experience.  My advice would be to seek out and speak to past employees.

review_title: Good but, Technology -Wise growth is less

most managers are managers just because they stayed for long time in organisation, not because of competence.

heavy amounts of support work in bangalore

review_title: If your life is your work - this company is just right

Way above average ambitions (may be viewed as a Con in certain contexts)
Internal mobility
Resources

Community programs

Management skills of tech managers may be below average

review_title: Compensation is not what it used to be. Lots of good people leaving
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: GS continues to have one of the highest concentrations of talent and people with high IQs. You will never be bored. You will always be challenged intellectually.
cons:
In the past 2 years there has been an increased number of leaders leaving on their own. Most believe the reason is what those that are still here see, an abrupt flat compensation. If you are a new joiners or just out of college, chances are you're going to get paid just a bit more than OK, but not great. Mostly in the form of a bonus. This is greatly because the firm needs to compete with other companies that pay better. Once you've been here more than a couple of years, your total comp starts to quickly plateau. Only about 10% of people that joined alongside you will actually reach a level of leadership that will get paid well consistently.

While people do still get promoted and are given some resemblance of leadership (oversee a project or 2-3 people) the true leadership aka mgr roles get filled from outside. So, if you have a 2-3 year plan its good. If you have a 5-10 year plan be ready to either be disappointed or snuggle up next to a mgr that influences careers.

Looks good on resume. Opens doors.

review_title: Long time employee sees rapid changes, and afraid they aren't for the better ...
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
- Really do believe that people are their greatest asset
- Invest heavily in internal training and education
- Increasing focus on work / life balance e.g More opportunities to work from home etc ...
- Strong balance between tactical and strategic solutions
- Fast paced, exciting workplace
- Fascinating technical and functional challenges
cons:
- The firm appears to has lost its identity in the Technology division, and is struggling to rebrand itself
- Rapid culture and structural changes rocking the boat a bit too much

pros: I joined Goldman Sachs after my bachelor's degree in India. It was a great work environment. Despite the unfavourable work-life balance, I learnt a lot about financial industry, and it helped me build a strong career foundation being a beginner in the field.
cons: It's difficult to strike a good work-life balance, but it certainly is not impossible. If you're lucky, you might end up in a stable team where there's less employee turnover.

review_title: Excellent place to work if you're willing to invest yourself
pros:
* Excellent compensation package & benefits
* First-rate professional development opportunities
* High-quality talent pool means your colleagues will be as amazing as you are
* The culture is very productive and supportive, provided you find the right team
cons:
* Working in-depth on proprietary systems can lead to a lack of transferrable skills when you leave
* Compensation is great...but you'll work for every last penny
* Leaving at 5PM is a half day

review_title: GS is a great place to work
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Great work environment with really talented people. Lots of interesting projects and issues arise daily at a fast pace that keeps the work interesting.
cons: The hours can be very long and the pay structure can be political and vary greatly from position to position. the environment can be high stress for individuals who are not accustomed to working in such environments.

job_title: Senior Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great co-workers, engaging work, meritocracy that recognizes talent and effort. Opportunities to develop and grow; community outreach.
cons: Work life balance is a struggle. Management says to not work crazy hours, but at the same time has expectations to keep 20 balls in the air at the same time, that no one of the team can do without long hours.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: You're surrounded by some of the brightest minds, where your manager gives you a great deal of responsibility. It is very regular at Goldman Sachs to have an analyst present to a very senior manager. Despite the shade that is sometimes
cons: Given so much responsibility, the analyst is expected to work extremely hard to live up to her manager's lofty expectations. This will needlessly result in working long hours. If you aren't okay with working long long hours, then this isn't the job for you.

review_title: I am a new joiner. So far it has been very good.
pros:
People are hardworking.
Everyone is from some IIT/NIT/BITS.
Everyone is smart around you.
One of the best firm to start career as you are given big projects as soon as you start.
World class gym.
cons:
Office is more work less fun. 
It is not a tech firm so don't expect pool tables, carrom, etc. 
Everyone is hardworking so you also need to work hard to compete with them. But yeah, it is also good in some sense.

pros: Excellent office facilities (canteen, tea coffee point, Forex desk for employee use, modern refurbishment, in house gym) Goldman provides excellent in house educational portal for ongoing self improvement - mandatory hours (10-20) for all levels.
cons: Work life balance not great (self driven, more difficult for desk support role) ie junior population tend to work hard/stay late to prove themselves to others.

review_title: Great Place, Not a Ton of Natural Lighting
pros:
-The company works on some really cool chemicals
-Excellent elevator system, very fast to get around the floors
-The benefits include options for laser hair removal, tuition reimbursement, and non-scheduled naps
-Fran has been the best manager ever
-Easy promotions
-Options to work overtime
cons:
-Not a ton of natural light
-I’m allergic to dogs, so bring your dog to work sucks for me
-Some of my coworkers have dead personalities 
-The layout can be a little confusing and I get lost sometimes

review_title: great place to work...but beware of certain managers
pros: the people - employees.  very helpful in the training
cons: management wasn't always fair with work and raises.  seemed to favor their 'friends' more than the way people worked

pros:
Reputation and salary
straight out of college I got a 10k signing bonus and a 65k salary having worked there for two summers.
cons:
incredebly long hours, don't expect to work less than 60-70 hrs a week and some weekends without overtime.
they really screwed us on the bonuses this year.

job_title: Operations Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Its a good place to work and the people are good for the most part. Good opportunities if you want to do the same thing for your entire career. Operations just isnt exciting work.  Good pay compared to similar companies.
cons: Not a good work life balance at all, they pay you just enough to think not spending time with family or any outside interests is just ok.  Analyst and Associate levels are the worker bees and are worked hard.

review_title: A good first job, a long career requires sacrifices
job_title: Business Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Very professional and best industry practices. Chance to interact with some very smart people. Competitive environment that will bring out the best out of anyone. Steep learning curve that leaves you satisfied by the end of a couple of years.
cons: People are not treated very well. When you are a junior, its not something you notice but after some years, it wears you down. Weekends, holidays and your personal life comes after your job. Face time and hype is sometimes more important than actual work.

pros:
If you are good, then you will prosper
transparent review process
company invests hugely in developing people and leadership
regular surveys to where people can anonymously raise their concerns and which are actually addressed
cons: you need to understand the culture of the company and then of the group and really get comfortable with it....this is not cons per se but lateral hires take a bit of time in getting into the groove

pros: you are definitely surrounded by the best of the best in each silo, and you can literally see the pressure radiating around each individual, day to day, to keep outdoing each other. In a very counter-intuitive way, culture encourages massive sharing of ideas and work internally to reduce redundancy and increase productivity + motivation.
cons: can never really see the entire picture of what is happening beyond your pay-grade, which can impact your hard earned compensations, or even employment status. still a boys club if you want to climb up.

review_title: Demanding but rewarding experience with upward mobility for strong performers
job_title: Financial Associate in New York, NY
pros:
*Significant responsibility given to junior employees, with opportunity for career advancement
*Highly competent colleagues that are both intelligent and efficient
*Offers much better than average pay relative to comparable positions at other firms
cons:
*Work/life balance could still use improvement, though hours are largely manager dependent and similar to that of other firms
*Bureaucracy and internal politics make the work environment fairly stressful at times

pros: I have met very few people who are not smart in this firm. Everyone at senior levels i.e Partner are very very competent, highly commercial and quite practical. The commitment to diversity etc is real. It is mostly a meritocracy.
cons: The firm needs to keep an eye on how much further the compensation ratio vs ROE tradeoff should go. Right now, it is pretty close to the point where there will be wider discontent. But needless to say this is something thats constantly discussed and watched internally.

pros:
Extremely extremely smart people- you _always_ learn something from interacting with anyone.
You get to do very diverse set of things, even an analyst can get a lot of opportunity to manage things. Everyday is full of accomplishments, and people treat their subordinates with respect and a lot of care so that they grow up. 
Life at work is great.
cons:
Somewhat individualistic culture, although from what I hear, it's still the most cooperative among banks.
Terribly long hours if you want to go up. Forget work life balance. no life outside work if you want to go up.

job_title: Loan Operations Associate in Irving, TX
pros: Driven and innovative colleagues. Ability to impact change even from lower levels. Great benefits. Many upper level managers are easy to talk to and willing to invest in your career development.

pros: Ambitious, sharp and friendly co-workers who you really enjoy working with. Great access to high-caliber people both internally at the firm and externally, who will inspire you. Goldman Sachs' globally recognized brand and vast network allows you to work with high-profile and challenging clients.
cons: Fairly hierarchical organisation, where years on the job takes a priority on average rather than talent. Plenty of internal and process-driven reporting which should be made more efficient.

pros: If you just finished your undergraduate, this is the best place to start. You spend many years here and learn a lot of different subjects. This is a place for you to build a career.
cons: You need to be here for a long time to be promoted, and you need to build a lot of relationship with others. So, if you have higher degrees or you are experienced, this place may not work properly for you. The job does not require much of a talent and it is rather easy to replace you with a new employee.

review_title: This is not investment banking, or even finance for that matter
job_title: Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Young employees joining every year, DJ D-Sol actually slaps

pros:

Intellectually satisfying work at the industry leader.  There are many opportunities to get great career-bosting experience by raising your hand for projects.
cons: Most people put in long hours; there is pressure to be "on" 24/7 to colleagues in Europe and Asia as well as in the US.  The environment, while team-based, is always competitive.  Not everyone is a good fit in that atmosphere.

review_title: Lots of hard work, but can be rewarding
pros: By far the most diverse, smart and talented group of individuals I ever had the pleasure to work with. It's amazing how whole divisions are so quick to react to changing environments.
cons: A few bad apples can really spoil the work environment.  Some individuals spend more energy playing politics than focussing on the job at hand.

pros: Top notch people and top notch projects. You'll learn from the best. It's a fantastic environment. Team oriented, very supportive.

job_title: Operations Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT

review_title: Good exposure, good inculcation of company work ethics and a great learning experience

review_title: Worked with very smart people and learnt a lot from its rich culture

review_title: A good place, for the most part

it is extremely political

review_title: It was great 10 years ago, but the culture has eroded

pros: Smart people, challenging projects. There's always an opportunity to learn from colleagues. In the past, opinions from team members of all levels were valued.
cons: The people who succeed now are the ones who think of themselves only and conduct themselves ruthlessly. The value of the team has eroded -- bad decisions are being made by senior leaders who no longer listen to the advice of their teams.

review_title: A Type People doing B Type Work
job_title: Finance Associate in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: People are great, training opps are endless and the opportunities to advance are good.  Firm promotes internal mobility and holds to it as long as you a good candidate.
cons: Work hours are long, very bureaucratic, work can be very monotonous at times.  The review process is ridiculously unhelpful and the bonus and promotion process is very political. pros: Great people.  Great culture.  Great synergies between different businesses.  Reputation greatly improved.  Highly commercial orientation.  Very good place to develop new skills particularly early in a career.
cons: Political at more senior levels.  Compensation trajectory flattening relative to the past.  Work life balance improving but still a challenge.  May be inflexible of different leadership styles.

pros:
The salary is Decent.
You get good Insurance
The culture within the organization is very Inclusive.
Great Opportunities to learn, both on the job and through classes.
Your'e Challenged by your projects.
cons:
No work life balance
Judgmental Environment. 
Too much about appearance, it is not enough to deliver.
Too much competition within teams. Though peopel are willing to help other people.

pros: Excellent company culture that engenders hard work, a competitive environment and superior performance. Great benefits including performance-based bonuses and great retirement matching.
cons: While GS makes a point to try to keep a good work/life balance, the environment is still very demanding, with plenty of last-minute demands. Because of the competitive culture you always have a sense of being disposable.

review_title: Still tops but losing it's edge
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Jersey City, NJ

job_title: Summer Analyst in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Operations Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
cons:
The work done, at least in operations, is intellectually insulting. A high school kid could do it since it is so repetitive. The system they used is ANCIENT, and office politics is awful.

job_title: Investment Banker in New York, NY
pros: Great support and promotion of innovative thinking. My putting in the hard work and hours your success is squarely on your shoulders. One of the best places on earth to work
cons: Life is what you make it. You can get online and complaint about the job you have and the people with whom you work, however, hard work and perseverance will always get you positive results.

review_title: Rewarding but not the easiest life

pros: The people that work here are some of the most amazing individuals. It certainly attracts the brightest and best. The business is founded on great principal and the services offered are unmatched.
cons: Pay is low, morale is low. It is sincerely set up to weed out most, retaining a few that stick it out to get promoted.

review_title: Good if you are in the right team with right people

cons: Politics, Low CTC and they dont increase much saying you get bonus and that too also not upto the mark if I compare myself I earn less as compared to outside market standard. Stressful work environment.

pros:
1. Good compensation.

job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY

review_title: Benefits that come at a steep price

review_title: A great place to work for someone who is looking to utilize teamwork skills in a fast pace financial setting.

Global exposure
